ORDER: On May 9, 2024, the Court issued an Order directing the parties to remove the exhibits admitted and depositions presented during the bench trial in this matter from Judge Boltons chambers within 30 days (by June 10, 2024), or the Clerk may destroy or otherwise dispose of those exhibits. As of this date, Plaintiffs' counsel have failed to do so. Therefore, IT IS ORDERED Plaintiffs' counsel shall pick up their exhibits by Thursday, July 18, 2024, or said exhibits shall be destroyed by the Clerk of the Court. Counsel shall immediately email chambers mailbox at bolton_chambers@azd.uscourts.gov to make arrangements with staff to retrieve their exhibits and depositions. Ordered by Senior Judge Susan R. Bolton on 6/18/2024. This is a TEXT ENTRY ONLY. There is no PDF document associated with this entry. (KMB) (Entered: 06/18/2024)

MINUTE ENTRY for proceedings held before Senior Judge Susan R Bolton: Motion Hearing, Discovery Dispute and Trial Scheduling Hearing held on 7/25/2023. Argument held on pending motions. IT IS ORDERED taking under advisement Docs. 364, 367, 390, 391, 393, 394, 396, 397 and 399 . Discussion held regarding the issues contained in the Notice and Request for Conference Regarding Case Schedule and Discovery Issues (Doc. 461 ). Regarding the discovery issue, IT IS ORDERED that counsel for Plaintiff Arizona Democratic Party and Democratic National Committee and counsel for Intervenor-Defendants, Warren Petersen and Ben Toma, file simultaneous memoranda not to exceed 10 pages regarding the disputed issue of legislative privilege no later than August 2, 2023. No replies may be filed. No other party may file a memorandum. Discussion held regarding setting the trial in this case. Estimated trial length: 10 days. IT IS ORDERED setting Bench Trial on November 6, 2023, at 9:00 a.m. in Courtroom 502. Trial will be held on the following days: November 6 through November 9, November 13 through November 17 and November 20 and November 21. Counsel Langhofer's request that trial not be held on November 17, 2023 will be addressed after trial commences. APPEARANCES: Hayden Johnson, Danielle Lang, Sadik Huseny, Niyati Shah, Bruce Samuels, Daniel Volchok, John Freedman, Joshua Messer, Allison Neswood, Christopher Dodge, Elisabeth Frost, Erika Cervantes, Ernest Herrera, Alexander Ritchie, Richard Dellheim and Jennifer Yun for Plaintiffs. Joshua Bendor, Kathryn Boughton, Timothy Horley, Joshua Whitaker, Craig Morgan, Shayna Stuart and Anna Critz for Defendants. Kory Langhofer and Thomas Basile for Intervenor Defendant Republican National Committee. Hannah Porter for Intervenor Defendants Warren Petersen and Ben Toma. (Court Reporter Teri Veres) Hearing held 10:04 AM to 12:02 PM and 12:15 PM to 12:32 PM. This is a TEXT ENTRY ONLY. There is no PDF document associated with this entry. (MAW) (Entered: 07/26/2023)

ORDER granting Plaintiffs' Cross-Motion for Summary Judgment (Doc. 391, 393 ); granting Tohono O'odham Plaintiffs' Motion for Summary Judgment (Doc. 390 ); granting Plaintiffs' Cross-Motion for Summary Judgment (Doc. 393, 396 ); denying the RNC's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether Arizona can reject any State Form without accompanying DPOC (Doc. 397 ); denying the State's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether H.B. 2243 violates Section 8(a) by allowing unlawful cancellation of registrations (Doc. 364 ); granting in part and denying in part the State's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether the Voting Laws violate Section 8(b) by mandating nonuniform and discriminatory list maintenance procedures (Doc. 364 ); denying as moot LUCHA's Cross-Motion for Summary Judgment under Sections 6 and 8(a) of the NVRA (Doc. 394 ); granting in part and denying in part the State's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether the Voting Laws violate the Materiality Provision of the Civil Rights Act by rejecting voter registrations that do not satisfy the Checkbox Requirement (Doc. 364 ); denying the State's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether the Voting Laws' Birthplace Requirement violates the Materiality Provision of the Civil Rights Act (Doc. 364 ); granting the State's Motion for Summary Judgment that the Voting Laws' purge provisions are not unconstitutionally vague (Doc. 364 ); denying as moot Poder Latinx's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether the Voting Laws violate  10101(a)(2)(A) of the Civil Rights Act by applying different standards or procedures to voters that the county recorder has reason to believe are non-citizens (Doc. 397 ); denying as moot the parties' Motions and Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment as to whether there is a private right of action under  10101 of the Civil Rights Act (Doc. 367, 397, 399 ). See Order for further details. Signed by Senior Judge Susan R Bolton on 9/13/23. (DXD) (Entered: 09/14/2023)

MINUTE ENTRY for proceedings held before Senior Judge Susan R. Bolton: Final Pretrial Conference held on 10/24/2023. Plaintiff's Motion for Extension of Time to Respond to Intervenor-Defendant the Republican National Committee's Rule 54(b) Motion (Doc. 574 ) is granted. Defendant's Motion for Clarification as to Trial of Claims Seeking Alternative Grounds for Relief (Doc. 555 ) is granted. Motion in Limine (Doc. 570 ) is taken under advisement. Republican National Committee's Motion in Limine re: Admissibility of Legal Opinions (Doc. 568 ) is a matter for objection at trial and will not be ruled on. Plaintiff's Motion in Limine re: Evidence of State Interest (Doc. 569 ) is granted. Plaintiff's Motion in Limine re: To Exclude Witnesses and Materials not Timely Disclosed (Doc. 567 ) is taken under advisement as to the new witness. As to materials not timely disclosed, counsel withdraws the motion. Plaintiffs' Motion in Limine to bar Intervenor-Defendants Ben Toma and Warren Petersen from Adducing Evidence at Trial (Doc. 566 ) is taken under advisement. The parties are directed to email to chambers mailbox no later than October 30, 2023, the Joint Proposed Pretrial Order (but not the over 8000 pages of Exhibits) in Word along with a Supplement to the Joint Proposed Pretrial Order amending the issues to be tried in light of the ruling on the Motion for Clarification. [See attached pdf for complete details.] (Court Reporter Scott Coniam) Hearing held 10:03 AM to 11:51 AM. (ESG) (Entered: 10/25/2023)

*AMENDED by Doc. 709 - ORDER declaring that A.R.S.  16-121.01(A) violates  10101(a)(2)(B) of the Civil Rights Act by denying Arizonans the right to vote based on errors or omissions that are not material to determining Arizonans eligibility to vote. Arizona may not reject State Form registrations that lack an individuals state or country of birth and must register an individual if that individual is found eligible to vote. FURTHER ORDERED declaring that A.R.S.  16-165(I) violates  10101(a)(2)(A) of the Civil Rights Act and section 8(b) of the NVRA by subjecting naturalized citizens whom county recorders have reason to believe are non-citizens to SAVE checks, which is a different standard, practice, or procedure than that applied to native-born citizens. Arizona may not conduct SAVE checks on any registered voter whom county recorders have reason to believe are a non-citizen. But Arizona may conduct SAVE checks on registered voters who have provided DPOC. See A.R.S.  16-165(I). FURTHER ORDERED declaring that A.R.S.  16-121.01(A) violates sections 6 and 7 of the NVRA by requiring Arizonans who register with the State Form to provide documentary proof of residence. Arizona may not reject State Form registrations that are not accompanied by documentary proof of residence but must register an individual without proof of residence as a Federal-Only Voter if that individual is otherwise eligible to vote. See order for complete details. Signed by Senior Judge Susan R. Bolton on 2/29/24. (NKS) *Modified to add amended docket text on 2/29/2024 (NKS). (Entered: 02/29/2024)

FINAL JUDGMENT - Defendants, their officers, agents, servants, employees, and attorneys, and anyone else in active concert or participation with them are: PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing such restrictions; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing this mandate and that Arizona must abide by the LULAC Consent Decree and register eligible State Form users without DPOC for federal elections; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing the checkbox requirement when a person provides DPOC and is otherwise eligible to vote; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing this requirement and may not reject State Form registrations that lack an individual's place of birth and must register an individual if that individual is found eligible to vote; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing this requirement and may not reject State Form registrations that lack documentary proof of location of residence but must register an otherwise eligible voter registrant as a Federal-Only Voter; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing these requirements within the 90-day period prior to the date of an election for federal office; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing this requirement and may not conduct citizenship checks using USCIS's SAVE system on registered voters whom county recorders have reason to believe lack U.S. citizenship. Judgment is otherwise entered in favor of Defendants on all other claims addressed in the Court's Partial Summary Judgment Order (Doc. 534 ) and Amended Order (Doc. 709 ). This Court shall retain jurisdiction to enforce the terms of this Final Judgment and to award such other relief as may be appropriate. See Judgment for further details. Signed by Senior Judge Susan R Bolton on 5/2/24. (DXD) (Entered: 05/02/2024)

AMENDED ORDER declaring that A.R.S.  16-121.01(A) violates  10101(a)(2)(B) of the Civil Rights Act by denying Arizonans the right to vote based on errors or omissions that are not material to determining Arizonans eligibility to vote. Arizona may not reject State Form registrations that lack an individuals state or country of birth and must register an individual if that individual is found eligible to vote. FURTHER ORDERED declaring that A.R.S.  16-165(I) violates  10101(a)(2)(A) of the Civil Rights Act and section 8(b) of the NVRA by subjecting naturalized citizens whom county recorders have reason to believe are non-citizens to SAVE checks, which is a different standard, practice, or procedure than that applied to native-born citizens. Arizona may not conduct SAVE checks on any registered voter whom county recorders have reason to believe are a non-citizen. But Arizona may conduct SAVE checks on registered voters who have not provided DPOC. See A.R.S.  16-165(I). FURTHER ORDERED declaring that A.R.S.  16-121.01(A) violates sections 6 and 7 of the NVRA by requiring Arizonans who register with the State Form to provide documentary proof of residence. Arizona may not reject State Form registrations that are not accompanied by documentary proof of residence but must register an individual without proof of residence as a Federal-Only Voter if that individual is otherwise eligible to vote. See order for complete details. Signed by Senior Judge Susan R. Bolton on 2/29/24. (NKS) (Entered: 02/29/2024)

MINUTE ENTRY for proceedings held before Senior Judge Susan R Bolton: Motion Hearing, Discovery Dispute and Trial Scheduling Hearing held on 7/25/2023. Argument held on pending motions. IT IS ORDERED taking under advisement Docs. 364, 367, 390, 391, 393, 394, 396, 397 and 399 . Discussion held regarding the issues contained in the Notice and Request for Conference Regarding Case Schedule and Discovery Issues (Doc. 461 ). Regarding the discovery issue, IT IS ORDERED that counsel for Plaintiff Arizona Democratic Party and Democratic National Committee and counsel for Intervenor-Defendants, Warren Petersen and Ben Toma, file simultaneous memoranda not to exceed 10 pages regarding the disputed issue of legislative privilege no later than August 2, 2023. No replies may be filed. No other party may file a memorandum. Discussion held regarding setting the trial in this case. Estimated trial length: 10 days. IT IS ORDERED setting Bench Trial on November 6, 2023, at 9:00 a.m. in Courtroom 502. Trial will be held on the following days: November 6 through November 9, November 13 through November 17 and November 20 and November 21. Counsel Langhofer's request that trial not be held on November 17, 2023 will be addressed after trial commences. APPEARANCES: Hayden Johnson, Danielle Lang, Sadik Huseny, Niyati Shah, Bruce Samuels, Daniel Volchok, John Freedman, Joshua Messer, Allison Neswood, Christopher Dodge, Elisabeth Frost, Erika Cervantes, Ernest Herrera, Alexander Ritchie, Richard Dellheim and Jennifer Yun for Plaintiffs. Joshua Bendor, Kathryn Boughton, Timothy Horley, Joshua Whitaker, Craig Morgan, Shayna Stuart and Anna Critz for Defendants. Kory Langhofer and Thomas Basile for Intervenor Defendant Republican National Committee. Hannah Porter for Intervenor Defendants Warren Petersen and Ben Toma. (Court Reporter Teri Veres) Hearing held 10:04 AM to 12:02 PM and 12:15 PM to 12:32 PM. This is a TEXT ENTRY ONLY. There is no PDF document associated with this entry. (MAW) (Entered: 07/26/2023)

ORDER granting Plaintiffs' Cross-Motion for Summary Judgment (Doc. 391, 393 ); granting Tohono O'odham Plaintiffs' Motion for Summary Judgment (Doc. 390 ); granting Plaintiffs' Cross-Motion for Summary Judgment (Doc. 393, 396 ); denying the RNC's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether Arizona can reject any State Form without accompanying DPOC (Doc. 397 ); denying the State's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether H.B. 2243 violates Section 8(a) by allowing unlawful cancellation of registrations (Doc. 364 ); granting in part and denying in part the State's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether the Voting Laws violate Section 8(b) by mandating nonuniform and discriminatory list maintenance procedures (Doc. 364 ); denying as moot LUCHA's Cross-Motion for Summary Judgment under Sections 6 and 8(a) of the NVRA (Doc. 394 ); granting in part and denying in part the State's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether the Voting Laws violate the Materiality Provision of the Civil Rights Act by rejecting voter registrations that do not satisfy the Checkbox Requirement (Doc. 364 ); denying the State's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether the Voting Laws' Birthplace Requirement violates the Materiality Provision of the Civil Rights Act (Doc. 364 ); granting the State's Motion for Summary Judgment that the Voting Laws' purge provisions are not unconstitutionally vague (Doc. 364 ); denying as moot Poder Latinx's Motion for Summary Judgment as to whether the Voting Laws violate  10101(a)(2)(A) of the Civil Rights Act by applying different standards or procedures to voters that the county recorder has reason to believe are non-citizens (Doc. 397 ); denying as moot the parties' Motions and Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment as to whether there is a private right of action under  10101 of the Civil Rights Act (Doc. 367, 397, 399 ). See Order for further details. Signed by Senior Judge Susan R Bolton on 9/13/23. (DXD) (Entered: 09/14/2023)

MINUTE ENTRY for proceedings held before Senior Judge Susan R. Bolton: Final Pretrial Conference held on 10/24/2023. Plaintiff's Motion for Extension of Time to Respond to Intervenor-Defendant the Republican National Committee's Rule 54(b) Motion (Doc. 574 ) is granted. Defendant's Motion for Clarification as to Trial of Claims Seeking Alternative Grounds for Relief (Doc. 555 ) is granted. Motion in Limine (Doc. 570 ) is taken under advisement. Republican National Committee's Motion in Limine re: Admissibility of Legal Opinions (Doc. 568 ) is a matter for objection at trial and will not be ruled on. Plaintiff's Motion in Limine re: Evidence of State Interest (Doc. 569 ) is granted. Plaintiff's Motion in Limine re: To Exclude Witnesses and Materials not Timely Disclosed (Doc. 567 ) is taken under advisement as to the new witness. As to materials not timely disclosed, counsel withdraws the motion. Plaintiffs' Motion in Limine to bar Intervenor-Defendants Ben Toma and Warren Petersen from Adducing Evidence at Trial (Doc. 566 ) is taken under advisement. The parties are directed to email to chambers mailbox no later than October 30, 2023, the Joint Proposed Pretrial Order (but not the over 8000 pages of Exhibits) in Word along with a Supplement to the Joint Proposed Pretrial Order amending the issues to be tried in light of the ruling on the Motion for Clarification. [See attached pdf for complete details.] (Court Reporter Scott Coniam) Hearing held 10:03 AM to 11:51 AM. (ESG) (Entered: 10/25/2023)

*AMENDED by Doc. 709 - ORDER declaring that A.R.S.  16-121.01(A) violates  10101(a)(2)(B) of the Civil Rights Act by denying Arizonans the right to vote based on errors or omissions that are not material to determining Arizonans eligibility to vote. Arizona may not reject State Form registrations that lack an individuals state or country of birth and must register an individual if that individual is found eligible to vote. FURTHER ORDERED declaring that A.R.S.  16-165(I) violates  10101(a)(2)(A) of the Civil Rights Act and section 8(b) of the NVRA by subjecting naturalized citizens whom county recorders have reason to believe are non-citizens to SAVE checks, which is a different standard, practice, or procedure than that applied to native-born citizens. Arizona may not conduct SAVE checks on any registered voter whom county recorders have reason to believe are a non-citizen. But Arizona may conduct SAVE checks on registered voters who have provided DPOC. See A.R.S.  16-165(I). FURTHER ORDERED declaring that A.R.S.  16-121.01(A) violates sections 6 and 7 of the NVRA by requiring Arizonans who register with the State Form to provide documentary proof of residence. Arizona may not reject State Form registrations that are not accompanied by documentary proof of residence but must register an individual without proof of residence as a Federal-Only Voter if that individual is otherwise eligible to vote. See order for complete details. Signed by Senior Judge Susan R. Bolton on 2/29/24. (NKS) *Modified to add amended docket text on 2/29/2024 (NKS). (Entered: 02/29/2024)

FINAL JUDGMENT - Defendants, their officers, agents, servants, employees, and attorneys, and anyone else in active concert or participation with them are: PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing such restrictions; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing this mandate and that Arizona must abide by the LULAC Consent Decree and register eligible State Form users without DPOC for federal elections; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing the checkbox requirement when a person provides DPOC and is otherwise eligible to vote; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing this requirement and may not reject State Form registrations that lack an individual's place of birth and must register an individual if that individual is found eligible to vote; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing this requirement and may not reject State Form registrations that lack documentary proof of location of residence but must register an otherwise eligible voter registrant as a Federal-Only Voter; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing these requirements within the 90-day period prior to the date of an election for federal office; PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from enforcing this requirement and may not conduct citizenship checks using USCIS's SAVE system on registered voters whom county recorders have reason to believe lack U.S. citizenship. Judgment is otherwise entered in favor of Defendants on all other claims addressed in the Court's Partial Summary Judgment Order (Doc. 534 ) and Amended Order (Doc. 709 ). This Court shall retain jurisdiction to enforce the terms of this Final Judgment and to award such other relief as may be appropriate. See Judgment for further details. Signed by Senior Judge Susan R Bolton on 5/2/24. (DXD) (Entered: 05/02/2024)

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 3 of 24
 
11   Plaintiffs Mi Familia Vota and Voto Latino, by and through their undersigned 
22   attorneys, file this Amended Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief against 
33   Defendants Katie Hobbs, in her official capacity as the Secretary of State of Arizona, Mark 
44   Brnovich, in his official capacity as the Attorney General of Arizona, and the above-
captioned County Recorder Defendants, each named in their official capacities. In support, 
55  
Plaintiffs allege the following: 
66  
NATURE OF THE CASE 
77  
1.  This  is  an  action  brought  under  the  U.S.  Constitution  to  safeguard  the 
88  
fundamental rights of hundreds of thousands of Arizonans, including the right to vote and 
99  
the state-protected right to vote early by mail, which are subject to due process protections. 
1100  
No right is more precious in a free country than that of having a voice in the election of 
1111  
those who make the laws under which, as good citizens, we must live. Other rights, even 
1122  
the most basic, are illusory if the right to vote is undermined. Wesberry v. Sanders, 376 
1133  
U.S. 1, 17 (1964). In this action, Plaintiffs challenge Arizonas latest effort to undermine 
1144  
that most precious right: the recently enacted H.B. 2492, which severely burdens the right 
1155   to vote and, in many cases, will deny that right entirely, disenfranchising eligible, lawful 
1166   voters in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.  
1177   2.  Arizona has a long and complex history of applying different registration and 
1188   voting requirements to different voters, which has caused portions of its law to be held in 
violation of federal law and has required the State to enter into an ongoing consent decree. 
1199  
See Arizona v. Inter Tribal Council of Ariz., Inc., 570 U.S. 1, 15 (2013); Consent Decree 
2200  
at  7-16,  LULAC  v.  Reagan,  No.  2:17-cv-04102-DGC  (June  18,  2018),  ECF  No.  37 
2211  
(Consent Decree). The result is a byzantine system in which Arizona has three classes of 
2222  
voters: (1) those who registered pre-2005 and did not have to show documentary proof of 
2233  
citizenship (because Arizona did not yet require it), who can vote in all elections; (2) those 
2244  
who  registered  post-2005  using  the  federal  form  required  by  the  National  Voter 
2255  
Registration Act (NVRA) (the Federal Form) and did not show documentary proof of 
2266  
citizenship, who can vote only in federal elections; and (3) those who registered post-2005 
2277  
and showed adequate proof of citizenship, who can vote in all elections. All of these voters 
2288  
are entitled to vote in elections for which they are qualified by mail, a right which Arizona 
  
-1- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 4 of 24
 
11   has provided to all voters for any reason since 1991. See A.R.S.  16-541. Further, under 
22   the ongoing consent decree, the state must (1) treat all registrants the same regardless of 
33   whether they use the state form or Federal Form, registering all voters for federal elections 
44   regardless of provided evidence of citizenship; and (2) check the motor vehicles database 
for citizenship documentation before limiting voters to federal-only elections. See Consent 
55  
Decree at 7-16. 
66  
3.  H.B. 2492 (the Proof of Citizenship Restriction), which was signed into 
77  
law on March 30, 2022, adds another confusing, discriminatory, and unconstitutional 
88  
impediment to this morass. Among other things, the Restriction will require new registrants 
99  
using the Federal Form to provide additional documentation if they want to vote in 
1100  
presidential  elections  or  vote  early  by  mail  for  any  office,  prohibit  those  currently 
1111  
registered using the Federal Form who registered without proof of citizenship from voting 
1122  
by mail or in presidential elections, and require long-registered Arizonans who never had 
1133  
to provide proof of citizenshipestimated to be close to 200,000 voters1to locate and 
1144   present additional documentation to vote in presidential elections.2 The law provides no 
1155   details concerning how long-registered voters will be notified that they must provide new 
1166   documents, or how they will be given an opportunity to do so, and also requires the 
1177   Attorney General to investigate and potentially prosecute voters who registered without 
1188   providing proof of citizenship. 
4.  The  Proof  of  Citizenship  Restriction  continues  a  baseless  assault  on 
1199  
Arizonas election system based on a conspiracy theory that non-citizens are voting, despite 
2200  
a persistent lack of credible evidence to support such claims. The Restriction is the newest 
2211  
in a series of cynical and bad faith attempts to use these politically motivated and false 
2222  
allegations to limit access to voting by eligible, lawful citizens. And the new laws 
2233  
2244  
 
1 See Laurie Roberts, Republicans want HOW MANY Arizonans to prove they have a right 
2255  
to  vote?,  The  Ariz.  Republic  (March  28,  2022,  9:12  AM), 
2266   https://www.azcentral.com/story/opinion/op-ed/laurieroberts/2022/03/28/arizona-voters-
may-soon-prove-right-vote-citizenship/7192260001/. 
2277  
2 On April 22, 2022, Arizona Governor Doug Ducey signed into law S.B. 1638, which 
provides that H.B 2492 is effective from and after December 31, 2022. S.B. 1638  4, 
2288  
55th Leg., 2d Reg. Sess. (Ariz. 2022). 
  
-2- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 5 of 24
 
11   limitations on early voting are particularly pernicious given the prevalence of early voting 
22   by mail in Arizona. In 2020, a record-setting 88 percent of voters used Arizonas early 
33   voting by mail system to cast their ballots. But, even before the pandemic, early voting was 
44   the most common form of voting in the state. In 2016, over 2 million Arizona votersor 
about 75 percent of those who participated in the electionused early voting. Even in 
55  
2008, more than a million votersor close to half of those participatingused early 
66  
voting. And, as more voters have turned to early voting by mail, Arizonas election 
77  
administrators have responded by diverting their resources to support mail-in voting, 
88  
anticipating that the overwhelming majority of Arizona voters will exercise their right to 
99  
vote by mail. As a result, in-person voting facilities and opportunities have dramatically 
1100  
decreased.  
1111  
5.  In other words, for decades Arizonas voting system has been oriented 
1122  
toward  supporting  and  facilitating  early  mail  voters.  It  was  well-tested  and  well-
1133  
established. There is no evidence that it was undermined or even vulnerable to abuse or 
1144  
fraud. Quite to the contrary, both Governor Doug Ducey and Secretary Hobbs have 
1155   repeatedly assured the public and the nation that false claims about the legitimacy of 
1166   Arizonas 2020 election are to be rejected, that the election was secure and fraud-free, and 
1177   that the results should be trusted. As Governor Ducey emphasized in response to attacks 
1188   on the integrity of the 2020 election: Weve been doing early voting since 1992, and 
claims about problems with the system or the election are unfounded.3 Despite these 
1199  
assurances,  multiple  lawsuits  and  contests  brought  by  the  Republican  Party,  former 
2200  
President Donald Trumps campaign, and their supporters have sought to cast doubt on the 
2211  
outcome of the 2020 election. Arizonas state and federal courts responded by rejecting 
2222  
those suits and repudiated their champions for their striking lack of evidence. For example, 
2233  
in a case brought by the Arizona Republican Party to challenge the legitimacy of Maricopa 
2244  
Countys audit, the Superior Court ordered the party to pay attorneys fees to the Secretary 
2255  
of State under A.R.S.  12-349 because the lawsuit was groundless, brought in bad 
2266  
faith, and served only to cast false shadows on the elections legitimacy. Order at 9-10, 
2277  
 
3  @DougDucey,  Twitter  (Nov.  30,  2020,  9:48  PM) 
2288  
https://twitter.com/dougducey/status/1333603891863191552? ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw. 
  
-3- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 6 of 24
 
11   Ariz. Republican Party v. Fontes, No. CV 2020-014553, (Mar. 12, 2021). 
22   6.  The same false narratives sowed the groundwork for the Proof of Citizenship 
33   Restriction, and now, as a result, tens of thousands of Arizonans will be forced to jump 
44   through unnecessary hoops to access the mail voting system upon which they have come 
to rely, and to vote in presidential elections whether by mail or in person. Some of those 
55  
lawful,  eligible  Arizona  voters  will  be  unable  to  clear  the  Restrictions  hurdles.  As 
66  
manifested by state officials full-throated defense of Arizonas election system in the 
77  
immediate aftermath of the November 2020 election, as well as multiple court decisions 
88  
related to the same, there are no state interests, much less compelling ones, to justify the 
99  
new imposition of these unjustifiable and disparate burdens. There is no evidence that any 
1100  
of Arizonas voting methods are beset by fraud, and no credible evidence that non-citizens 
1111  
are attempting to overcome (much less actually overcoming) the numerous safeguards 
1122  
Arizona has put in place to limit voting in Arizona to United States citizens. The Proof of 
1133  
Citizenship Restriction is an entirely illegitimate and unconstitutional roadblock erected in 
1144  
the path of lawful, eligible voters. For these reasons and those detailed below, Plaintiffs 
1155   respectfully  request  a  declaration  that  the  Proof  of  Citizenship  Restriction  is 
1166   unconstitutional and an order enjoining its enforcement. 
1177   JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
1188   7.  Plaintiffs bring this action pursuant to 42 U.S.C.  1983 and 1988 to redress 
the deprivation, under the color of state law, of their rights under the First and Fourteenth 
1199  
Amendments to the U.S. Constitution  
2200  
8.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction to hear Plaintiffs claims pursuant 
2211  
to 28 U.S.C.  1331, 1343, and 1357. 
2222  
9.  This Court has jurisdiction over the Secretary of State, as she is sued in her 
2233  
official capacity as an elected official in Arizona. Further, the Secretary works and resides 
2244  
in the State of Arizona.  
2255  
10.  This Court has jurisdiction over the Attorney General, as he is sued in his 
2266  
official capacity as an elected official in Arizona. Further, the Attorney General works and 
2277  
resides in the State of Arizona. 
2288  
11.  This Court has jurisdiction over the County Recorder Defendants, as they are 
  
-4- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 7 of 24
 
11   sued in their official capacities as elected officials in Arizona, and they work or reside in 
22   the State of Arizona. 
33   12.  Venue is proper under 28 U.S.C.  1391(b) because a substantial part of the 
44   events or omissions giving rise to the claims occurred in this judicial district and in this 
division. 
55  
13.  This  Court  has  the  authority  to  grant  declaratory  and  injunctive  relief 
66  
pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  2201 and 2202. Further, this Court has the authority to enter a 
77  
declaratory judgment and to provide preliminary and permanent injunctive relief pursuant 
88  
to Rules 57 and 65 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.  
99  
PARTIES 
1100  
14.  Plaintiff Mi Familia Vota (MFV) is a national, non-profit civic engagement 
1111  
organization with a mission of uniting Latino, immigrant, and allied communities to 
1122  
promote social and economic justice through increased civic participation by encouraging 
1133  
leadership development, citizenship, and issue organizing. MFV encourages non-partisan 
1144  
voter registration and voter participation and has challenged voter suppression around the 
1155   nation. See, e.g., Mi Familia Vota v. Hobbs, No: 2:21-cv-01423-DWL (D. Ariz. filed Aug. 
1166   17, 2021); Mi Familia Vota v. Abbott, 497 F. Supp. 3d 195 (W.D. Tex. 2020). It has 
1177   operations in six states, including Arizona, where it is headquartered. More than 14,000 
1188   Arizonans follow and engage with MFV via email and/or MFVs social media platforms. 
15.  In advance of the 2020 election, MFV organized voter registration drives and 
1199  
conducted get-out-the-vote activities. MFV helped countless Arizonans register to vote 
2200  
using a Federal Form and helped countless Arizonans register to vote by mail. MFV also 
2211  
conducted  voter  education  campaigns  and  provided  other  voter  assistance,  including 
2222  
driving voters to polling locations.  
2233  
16.  MFV plans to organize the same activities for future elections. As a result of 
2244  
the Proof of Citizenship Restriction, however, MFV must divert money, personnel, time, 
2255  
and resources away from other programming in order to dedicate more resources toward 
2266  
efforts  to  ensure  that  voters  can  navigate  the  restrictions  imposed  by  the  Proof  of 
2277

STATEMENT OF FACTS 
1100  
A. Arizona has a long and tortured history of changing voter registration 
1111   systems. 
1122  
38.  Despite the lack of any credible fraud allegations, there has been a decades-
1133   long effort in Arizonaas the states electorate has become more diverseto restrict the 
1144   franchise and impose unjustifiable impediments to the right to vote. These changes have 
1155   led to disenfranchisement, multiple conflicting systems, and repeated litigation.  
1166   39.  As is particularly relevant here, in 2004 Arizona voters adopted Proposition 
200, a ballot initiative purportedly designed to combat voter fraud by requiring voters to 
1177  
present proof of citizenship when they register to vote and to present identification when 
1188  
they vote on election day. Purcell v. Gonzalez, 549 U.S. 1, 2 (2006) (per curiam). 
1199  
Proposition 200 amended the states election code to require county recorders to reject 
2200  
any application for registration that is not accompanied by satisfactory evidence of United 
2211  
States citizenship. A.R.S.  16166(F). This requirement was seemingly in direct conflict 
2222  
with the NVRA, which requires states to accept and use a standard federal registration 
2233  
form for voter registration (the Federal Form) that does not require applicants to provide 
2244  
documentary proof of citizenship. 52 U.S.C.  20505. And, in fact, the Supreme Court held 
2255  
in 2013 that the NVRA precluded Arizona from requiring applicants who used the NVRAs 
2266  
Federal Form to submit information beyond that required by the form itself. Inter Tribal 
2277   Council of Ariz., 570 U.S. at 15 (We conclude that . . . a state-imposed requirement of 
2288   evidence of citizenship not required by the Federal Form is inconsistent with the NVRAs

11   mandate that States accept and use the Federal Form. (quoting Ex parte Siebold, 100 
22   U.S. 371, 397 (1880))).   
33   40.  Nonetheless, the Supreme Courts ruling in Inter Tribal Council left open the 
44   possibility of imposing different requirements for voters in state and local elections than 
federal elections. Then-Attorney General Thomas Horne issued an Opinion on October 7, 
55  
2013 stating that such a system was required to comply with both state law and the NVRA, 
66  
see  Ariz.  Atty  Gen.  Op.  No.  I13-011  (Oct.  7,  2013),  available  at 
77  
https://www.azag.gov/sites/default/files/2018-06/I13-011.pdf (last visited Mar. 30, 2022), 
88  
and then-Secretary of State Ken Bennett subsequently implemented Arizonas bifurcated 
99  
voter registration system, which has been in place ever since.  
1100  
41.  Under this bifurcated system, Arizona has three classes of voters: (1) those 
1111  
who registered pre-2005 and did not have to show proof of citizenship, who have been 
1122  
permitted to vote in all elections; (2) those who registered post-2005 using the Federal 
1133  
Form and did not show evidence of citizenship, who have been permitted to vote only in 
1144  
federal elections; and (3) those who registered post-2005 and showed adequate proof of 
1155   citizenship,  who  have  been  permitted  to  vote  in  all  elections.  Prior  to  the  Proof  of 
1166   Citizenship Restriction, all of these voters were entitled to vote in elections for which they 
1177   were qualified by mail, a right which Arizona has provided to all voters for any reason 
1188   since 1991. See A.R.S.  16-541. 
42.  This bifurcated system has already led to disenfranchisement and confusion, 
1199  
resulting in further litigation. For example, prior to 2018, voters who used Arizonas state 
2200  
registration form and provided no evidence of citizenship were not registered to vote in 
2211  
any elections, while voters who undertook the same process but used the Federal Form to 
2222  
register were registered to vote in federal elections. See generally Consent Decree. Whats 
2233  
more, because Arizona has documentary proof of citizenship for some citizens from their 
2244  
drivers license application, some citizens who register to vote with the Federal Form have 
2255  
already provided proof of citizenship in a means that is easily verifiable, and the state can 
2266  
easily search for such voters documentation and allow them to vote in all elections. Id. 
2277  
43.  Due to these issues, in 2017, the League of United Latin American Citizens 
2288  
Arizona and the Arizona Students Association sued then-Secretary of State Michele

voter registration system. 
1122  
64.  Third, the law will require hundreds of thousands of voters who never had to 
1133  
provide further documentation to do so if they wish to continue to vote in presidential 
1144  
elections or, for Federal Form voters, to continue voting early by mail for any election. For 
1155   many voters who lack such documentation, the costs in time and effort to obtain it are 
1166   substantial, and result in many voters simply giving up and being disenfranchised. Other 
1177   courts considering challenges to similar laws have found these consequences to constitute 
1188   a substantial burden on the right to vote. See, e.g., Fish v. Schwab, 957 F.3d 1105, 1131 
(10th Cir. 2020), cert. denied, 141 S. Ct. 965 (2020) (explaining that extensive testimony 
1199  
about individual voters like Mr. Fish and Ms. Bucci who lacked [proof of citizenship] or 
2200  
faced significant costs to obtain it permitted the district court [to] properly conclude here 
2211  
that the [citizenship documentation] requirement imposed a significant burden on the right 
2222  
to vote); League of Women Voters of U.S. v. Newby, 838 F.3d 1, 13 (D.C. Cir. 2016) (It 
2233  
does not matter whether that is because they lack access to the requisite documentary proof 
2244  
or simply because the process of obtaining that proof is so onerous that they give up. The 
2255  
outcome is the samethe abridgment of the right to vote.). 
2266  
65.  Fourth, the law subjects potential voters to investigation by the Attorney 
2277  
General based solely on a county recorders inability to locate them in certain enumerated 
2288  
databases. Such inability could result from something as simple as a typographical or 
  
-16- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 19 of 24
 
11   transcription error, and fear of wrongful investigation may chill otherwise eligible voters 
22   from seeking to register to vote or exercising the franchise.  
33   66.  Taken together, this host of harms constitutes a substantial burden on the 
44   right to vote. 
F.  The Proof of Citizenship Restriction serves no justifiable state interest. 
55  
66   67.  As with so many pernicious voting restrictions, proponents of the Proof of 
Citizenship Restriction justify it by invoking the boogeyman of voter fraud without any 
77  
proof  to  support  their  claims.  During  the  Legislatures  consideration  of  the  Bill,  no 
88  
legislator identified a single instance of voter fraud or impropriety in Arizona related to 
99  
mail-in early voting ballots that would precipitate the need for the changes at issue. Instead, 
1100  
evidence-free assertions were offered such as that by Bill Sponsor Rep. Jake Hoffman, who 
1111  
stated that the Bill was needed because Arizona cannot allow potentially tens of thousands 
1122  
of noncitizens to vote in our elections.14 This unsupported fearmongering is plainly 
1133  
insufficient to justify the Proof of Citizenship Restrictions widespread burdens. 
1144  
68.  Meanwhile,  the  Legislatures  own  lawyers  advised  that  the  Proof  of 
1155  
Citizenship Restriction violates federal law and invites litigation.15 Indeed, Speaker Pro 
1166  
Tempore of the Arizona House Travis Grantham acknowledged that a motivation behind 
1177  
the law is to broadly challenge the constitutionality of the NVRA, stating that the law was 
1188   important to fight for local control of our elections and that challenging related federal 
1199  
2200  
2211  
 
2222  
14 See Katya Schwenk, Extreme Arizona Elections Bill Inching Closer to Law, Phoenix 
New  Times  (March  30,  2022,  6:00  AM), 
2233  
https://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/news/extreme-arizona-elections-bills-inching-closer-
2244   to-law-13323436. 
15 See Trevor Potter, This Arizona bill could keep you from voting early, by mail or for 
2255  
president,  AZ  Central  (March  27,  2022,  6:00  AM), 
2266   https://www.azcentral.com/story/opinion/op-ed/2022/03/27/arizona-bill-could-keep-you-
voting-early-president/7158739001/; Howard Fischer, GOP lawmakers seek to reopen 
2277  
legal  voting  issue,  Daily  Independent  (March  26,  2022,  9:00  AM), 
https://www.yourvalley.net/stories/gop-lawmakers-seek-to-reopen-legal-voting-
2288  
issue,293949. 
  
-17- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 20 of 24
 
11   rulings was a fight worth having.16 But disagreement with and open defiance of federal 
22   law is also insufficient to justify the Proof of Citizenship Restrictions significant burdens 
33   on Arizonans voting rights. 
44   69.  Other courts have rightfully found similar laws to be unconstitutional. For 
example, in 2011 Kansas adopted a law that required state and county election officials to 
55  
reject voter registration applications unless the applicant submitted satisfactory evidence 
66  
of United States citizenship. Fish, 957 F.3d at 1111 (quoting Secure and Fair Elections 
77  
(SAFE) Act, ch. 56,  8(l), 2011 Kan. Sess. Laws 795, 806, 80911 (codified at Kan. 
88  
Stat. Ann.  252309(l))). The United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit 
99  
ultimately held that the Kansas law violated the Fourteenth Amendments Equal Protection 
1100  
Clause because it was an unconstitutional burden on the right to vote and that it was also 
1111  
preempted by Section 5 of the NVRA. Id. at 1121. The Court found particularly relevant 
1122  
the  fact  that  the  Kansas  law  impacted  31,089  applicants  who  were  prevented  from 
1133  
registering to vote distinguished this from other voting restrictions where the burden was 
1144  
less clear. See id. at 1129.  
1155   70.  As noted above, the Proof of Citizenship Restriction imposes significant new 
1166   restrictions and burdens on a minimum of approximately 200,000 Arizonans, an impact 
1177   over six times greater than that which gave the Tenth Circuit such pause in Fish. As in 
1188   Fish,  there  can  be  little  doubt  that  the  Proof  of  Citizenship  Restriction  imposes  an 
unconstitutional burden on the right to vote. 
1199  
CLAIMS FOR RELIEF 
2200  
COUNT I 
2211  
Unjustifiable Burden on the Right to Vote  
2222  
U.S. Const. Amend. I, XIV, 42 U.S.C.  1983 
(As to all Defendants) 
2233  
 
2244   71.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference paragraphs 1 through 70 as if 
2255   fully set forth herein. 
2266  
 
2277  
16 See  Howard  Fischer,  GOP  lawmakers  seek  to  reopen  legal  voting  issue,  Daily 
Independent  (March  26,  2022,  9:00  AM),  https://www.yourvalley.net/stories/gop-
2288  
lawmakers-seek-to-reopen-legal-voting-issue,293949. 
  
-18- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 21 of 24
 
11   72.  A court considering a challenge to a state election law must carefully balance 
22   the character and magnitude of injury to the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights that 
33   the Plaintiffs seek to vindicate against the justifications put forward by the state for the 
44   burdens imposed by the rule. Burdick v. Takushi, 504 U.S. 428, 434 (1992); Anderson v. 
Celebrezze, 460 U.S. 780, 789 (1983).  
55  
73.  However slight th[e] burden may appear, . . . it must be justified by relevant 
66  
and legitimate state interests sufficiently weighty to justify the limitation. Crawford v. 
77  
Marion  Cnty.  Election  Bd.,  553  U.S.  181,  191  (2008)  (Stevens,  J.,  controlling  op.) 
88  
(quotations marks omitted).  
99  
74.  The Proof of Citizenship Restriction imposes a disparate and unjustifiable 
1100  
burden on the right to vote. As detailed above, it strips voters of the right to vote in 
1111  
presidential elections or by mail without notice, adds further confusion to what was already 
1122  
a convoluted registration process that has led to disenfranchisement, imposes substantial 
1133  
new costs on hundreds of thousands of Arizonans to exercise the franchise, and exposes 
1144  
voters to the threat of baseless investigation by the Attorney General. Both individually 
1155   and in combination these harms impose a significantand in many cases severeburden 
1166   on the right to vote. 
1177   75.  The Proof of Citizenship Restriction also arbitrarily treats Arizona voters 
1188   differently based solely on which voter registration form they happen to use. Those voters 
registering using the Federal Form without proof of citizenship will be entitled to vote in 
1199  
federal  congressional  elections,  while  the  same  voter  presenting  the  same  proof  of 
2200  
eligibility but using a state form will have their registration rejected entirely. Such equal 
2211  
protection  concerns  regarding  elections  law  are  also  properly  evaluated  under  the 
2222  
Anderson-Burdick framework.  See, e.g., Dudum v. Arntz, 640 F.3d 1098, 1106 n.15 (9th 
2233  
Cir. 2011). 
2244  
76.  These burdens are not justified by any sufficient state interest.  
2255  
2266  
2277  
2288  
  
-19- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 22 of 24
 
11   COUNT II 
22   Denial of Procedural Due Process 
U.S. Const. Amend. XIV, 42 U.S.C.  1983 
33  
(As to all Defendants) 
44    
77.  Plaintiffs reallege and reincorporate by reference paragraphs 1 through 70 as 
55  
though fully set forth herein. 
66  
78.  To determine whether a plaintiff has been denied procedural due process in 
77  
violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, a court first asks 
88  
whether a constitutionally protected liberty interest is at stake. If so, the court determines 
99  
whether the procedural protections provided are sufficient by applying the Anderson-
1100   Burdick test as described above. Ariz. Democratic Party v. Hobbs, 18 F.4th 1179, 1195 
1111   (9th Cir. 2021) (holding that the Anderson/Burdick approach is better suited to the context 
1122   of election laws than is the more general Eldridge test (quoting Richardson v. Tex. Secy 
1133   of State, 978 F.3d 220, 234 (5th Cir. 2020))).  
79.  The right to vote is a fundamental constitutional right. Harper v. Va. State 
1144  
Bd. of Elections, 383 U.S. 663, 667 (1966). Other rights, even the most basic, are illusory 
1155  
if the right to vote is undermined. Wesberry, 376 U.S. at 17. Because Arizona allows all 
1166  
registered voters to exercise their fundamental right to vote early by mail, there is a 
1177  
constitutionally protected liberty interest involved in the process of casting a ballot by mail 
1188  
and in having that ballot counted. See, e.g., Democracy N.C. v. N.C. State Bd. of Elections, 
1199  
476  F.  Supp  3d  158,  227  (M.D.N.C.  2020)  (holding  that  North  Carolina,  having 
2200  
authorized the use of absentee ballots, must afford appropriate due process protections to 
2211  
the use of the absentee ballots); Martin v. Kemp, 341 F. Supp. 3d 1326, 1338 (N.D. Ga. 
2222  
2018) (Courts around the country have recognized that [w]hile it is true that absentee 
2233  
voting is a privilege and a convenience to voters, this does not grant the state the latitude 
2244   to deprive citizens of due process with respect to the exercise of this privilege.) (quoting 
2255   Raetzel v. Parks/Bellemont Absentee Election Bd., 762 F. Supp. 1354, 1358 (D. Ariz. 
2266   1990)); Zessar v. Helander, No. 05 C 1917, 2006 WL 642646, at *5 (N.D. Ill. Mar. 13, 
2277   2006) (The right to vote by absentee ballot is not, in and of itself, a fundamental right. But 
once the State permits voters to vote absentee, it must afford appropriate due process 
2288  
  
-20- 
PLAINTIFFS AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND 
INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 38   Filed 05/13/22   Page 23 of 24
 
11   protections, including notice and a hearing, before rejecting an absentee ballot.). As a 
22   result, Defendants may not deprive voters of the right to vote early by mail without 
33   providing adequate procedures. 
44   80.  Arizonas  Proof  of  Citizenship  Restriction  will  deprive  hundreds  of 
thousands of currently registered voters of their ability to vote by mail in future elections. 
55  
It does so while giving no details about any notice these voters will be provided, or how or 
66  
when they may cure this defect. 
77  
81.  As  detailed  above,  there  is  no  state  interest  which  justifies  stripping 
88  
registered voters of the state-protected right to vote early by mail with no notice or 
99  
opportunity to cure. 
1100  
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
1111  
Plaintiffs respectfully request that this Court enter the following judgment: 
1122  
A. Declare that the Proof of Citizenship Restriction (H.B. 2492) violates the First 
1133  
and Fourteenth Amendments; 
1144  
B. Enjoin Defendants, along with their respective agents, officers, employees, and 
1155   successors from enforcing the Proof of Citizenship Restriction; 
1166   C. Award Plaintiff its costs, expenses, and reasonable attorneys fees, pursuant to 
1177   42 U.S.C.  1988, and any other applicable law; 
1188   D. Grant such other and further relief as the Court deems just and proper. 
1199    
Dated: May 13, 2022      Respectfully Submitted, 
2200

2 Amicus curiae Advocates for Victims of Illegal Alien Crime (AVIAC) is a 26 
3
U.S.C.  501(c)(3) non-profit organization that was founded in 2017.  AVIAC is led by 
4
individuals who have lost family members because of crimes committed by undocumented 
5
6 immigrants.2  AVIACs mission includes being a source of support for such victims across 
7
the country and a resource for policies that will enforce the nations immigration laws and 
8
prevent governmental incentives for illegal immigration. 
9
AVIAC objects to providing non-citizens with the right to vote in any election, 
10
11
whether local, state, or federal as it dilutes the votes of eligible U.S. citizens. Proof of 
12
citizenship is fundamental to ensuring that only U.S. citizens vote to protect Americas 
13
representative democracy. This case concerns the attempt by several Plaintiffs to override 
14
15 the United States Constitutions requirements that only U.S. citizens vote in elections, the 
16
Constitution of the State of Arizona and House Bill 2492, which requires proof of U.S. 
17
citizenship to vote in elections. AVIAC supports the State of Arizonas Consolidated 
18
19 Motion to Dismiss based on Plaintiffs failure to state a viable claim, including but not 
20
limited to, violations of the National Voter Registration Act of 1993.    
21
Given its interest in strong borders and the protection of national sovereignty, 
22
AVIAC has an interest in the continuation of the United States as a democracy in which 
23
24
 
25
1 
All parties with the exception Plaintiff and Plaintiff-Intervenors Mi Familia Vota, Poder Latinex, Chicanos Por La 
26 Causa and Chicanos Por La Causa Action Fund have consented to the filing of this brief by Amicus. Pursuant to 
F.R.CIV.P. 7 and FED. R. APP. P. 29(a)(4)(E), undersigned counsel certifies that: counsel for the Amicus authored this 
27 brief in whole; no counsel for a party authored this brief in any respect; and no person or entity  other than Amicus, 
its members, and its counsel  contributed monetarily to this briefs preparation or submission. 
28  
2 https://www.aviac.us/ (viewed Aug. 21, 2022). 
1 
 

 
the people of the United Statesthat is, U.S. citizensare the sovereigns representatives. 
1
2 AVIAC is concerned about incursions on the sovereignty of American citizens by non-
3
citizens voting in local, state and federal elections. Accordingly, AVIAC seeks to ensure 
4
that only American citizens are permitted to vote in Arizonas municipal, county, statewide 
5
6 and federal elections. 
7
SUMMARY OF ARGUMENT 
8
Every state has the right to prevent non-citizens from voting in local, state, and 
9
national elections.  In fact, the United States Constitution excludes non-citizens from the 
10
11
privilege, and with good reason.  Regulation of the electoral process receives unusual 
12
scrutiny because the right to exercise the franchise in a free and unimpaired manner is 
13
preservative of other basic civil and political rights.  Mathews v. Diaz, 426 U.S. 67, 78-
14
15 79, 96 S. Ct. 1883, 1890-91 (1976), quoting Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 562; 84 S.Ct. 
16
1362; 12 L.Ed.2d 506 (1964).  See also, Dunn v. Blumstein, 405 U.S. 330, 336; 92 S. Ct. 
17
995; 31 L. Ed. 2d 274 (1972).  In other words, the right to vote is accorded extraordinary 
18
19 treatment because it is, in equal protection terms, an extraordinary right: a citizen cannot 
20
hope to achieve any meaningful degree of individual political equality if granted an inferior 
21
right of participation in the political process.  Plyler v Doe, 457 U.S. 202, 233; 102 S. Ct. 
22
2382; 72 L. Ed. 2d 786, 810 (1982).  The Court has further stated that [t]he fact that all 
23
24
persons, aliens and citizens alike, are protected by the Due Process Clause does not lead to 
25
the  further  conclusion  that  all  aliens  are  entitled  to  enjoy  all  the  advantages  of 
26
citizenship.  [A] host of constitutional and statutory provisions rest on the premise that 
27
28 a legitimate distinction between citizens and aliens may justify attributes and benefits for 
2 
 

 
one class not accorded to the other, [e.g.,] [t]he Constitution protects the privileges and 
1
2 immunities only of citizens, Amdt. 14,  1; see Art. IV,  2, cl. 1, and the right to vote only 
3
of citizens. Amdts. 15, 19, 24, 26. Mathews, supra at 78-79, n. 12. 
4
Not only does the Constitution protect citizens right to vote, but nothing in that 
5
6 document could ever authorize the executive, legislative or judicial branch of the federal 
7
government to force the states  to allow non-citizens  to exercise  the same  privileges 
8
accorded citizens of the United States and of the several states.  Moreover, the States have 
9
a compelling right (and interest) in preserving the integrity of their election processes by 
10
11
ensuring that it protects against fraud and assures citizens of its integrity so that they will 
12
exercise their right to vote with vigor and confidence. 
13
ARGUMENT 
14
15 I.  ARIZONAS PROOF OF CITIZENSHIP REQUIREMENT IS 
CONSTITUTIONAL AND DOES NOT VIOLATE THE NVRA 
16
 
17 Arizona has had a citizenship requirement for voting since it became a State in 1912. 
18
Ariz. Const., Art. VII,  2. While the Arizona Constitution itself does not prescribe the 
19
qualifications of voters, it does provide that, [n]o person shall be entitled to vote at any 
20
21 general election,, or upon any question which may be submitted to a vote of the people, 
22
unless such person be a citizen of the United States  Id.  See also Ahrens v. Kerby, 44 
23
Ariz. 269, 340, 37 P.2d 375, 377 (1934) (emphasis added). 
24
The Arizona Constitution further requires that [t]here shall be enacted registration 
25
26 and other laws to secure the purity of elections and guard against abuses of the elective 
27
franchise. Ariz. Const, art. VII,  12. This requirement places an affirmative duty upon 
28
3 
 

 
the Arizona Legislature to ensure the integrity of elections. Ahrens at 44 Ariz. 269, 341, 37 
1
2 P.2d 375, 377 (In fact, in section 12 of this article 7, it places upon the law-making branch 
3
of the government the duty of enacting registration and other laws to secure the purity of 
4
elections and guard against abuses of the elective franchise.).   
5
6 In fulfilling Arizonas constitutional requirements, the Arizona legislature passed 
7
an amendment that requires voter registrants to submit proof of citizenship - Arizona HB 
8
2492. The Plaintiffs and Plaintiff-Interveners object to this law for several reasons, among 
9
them,  the  United  States,  which  incorrectly  alleges  that  because  the  National  Voter 
10
11
Registration Act requires merely an attestation but does not require proof of citizenship, 
12
the State of Arizona may not require the latter.  See U.S.A. v. State of Arizona, 2:22-cv-
13
01124-SRB. (The Federal Form specifies that an applicant must be a United States citizen 
14
15 to vote in federal elections, requires the applicant to attest to the applicants citizenship 
16
52 U.S.C.  20508(b)(2)). 
17
This is nonsense.  Under the existing Constitution of the United States, the federal 
18
19 government, acting through the Executive, Legislative, or Judicial branch, cannot force a 
20
state to allow people who are not citizens of the United States to cast votes in federal 
21
elections. States are not required to accept applicants for voter registration who cannot 
22
prove United States Citizenship.  Arizona v. Inter Tribal Council of Ariz., Inc., 570 U.S. 1, 
23
24
15; 133 S. Ct. 2247; 186 L.Ed.2d 239 (2013).  And indeed, as to Time, Place, and Manner, 
25
the requirement that an eligible voter prove United States citizenship is constitutional and 
26
unassailable by the federal government.  Id. 
27
28
4 
 

 
The Elections Clause empowers Congress to regulate how federal elections are held, 
1
2 but  not  who  may  vote  in  them.    Nothing  in  the  Constitution  provides  that  voting 
3
qualifications in federal elections are to be set by Congress.  Id. at 16, citing Oregon v. 
4
Mitchell, 400 U.S. 112, 210; 91 S.Ct. 260; 27 L.Ed.2d 272 (1970) (Harlan, J., concurring 
5
6 in part and dissenting in part); see also U.S. Term Limits v. Thornton, 514 U. S. 779, 833-
7
834; 115 S. Ct. 1842; 131 L. Ed. 2d 881 (1995); Tashjian v. Republican Party of Conn., 
8
479 U. S. 208, 231-232; 107 S. Ct. 544; 93 L.Ed. 2d 514 (1986) (Stevens, J., dissenting).  
9
If  an  applicant  is  unable  to  prove  citizenship,  the  state  can  reject  that  applicants 
10
11
registration.  Id. 
12
The requirement of national citizenship to vote in national elections was never in 
13
doubt among the framers of the Constitution.  The Supreme Court has consistently shored 
14
15 up the notion that non-citizens are not, and should not be, entitled to vote in federal 
16
elections.3  There is an unwritten, but just as fundamental, right and privilege of national 
17
citizenship to vote in national elections.  Ex parte Yarbrough, 110 U.S. 651, 665; 4 S. Ct. 
18
19 152; 28 L. Ed. 274 (1884); Wiley v. Sinkler, 179 U.S. 58; 21 S. Ct. 17; 45 L.Ed. 84, 88 
20
(1900).  In Yarbrough, in ruling that Congress had the power to enact the Fifteenth 
21
Amendment to prohibit the states from denying the right to vote to citizens on the basis of 
22
race, the Court noted it was merely affirmation of a guarantee as necessary to the right of 
23
24
 
25 3 Congress has also reaffirmed this principle in various statutory provisions. See e.g., 18 U.S.C.  611 (it is a crime 
punishable by a fine and up to one year in prison for an alien to vote in a federal election); 8 U.S.C.  1227 (any alien 
26 who has voted in violation of any Federal, State, or local constitutional provision, statute, ordinance, or regulation is 
deportable); 42 U.S.C.  1973gg-10(2) (any false statement concerning an applicants citizenship status that is made 
27 on a registration form submitted to election authorities is a crime); 18 U.S.C.  911 (knowing and willful false 
assertions of United States citizenship in order to vote are punishable by up to three years in prison) 18 U.S.C.  
28 1015(f) (it is a criminal offense for an individual to make a false statement or claim that he or she is a citizen of the 
United States in order to register or to vote). 
5 
 

 
other citizens to voteand to the right to vote in general as to the right to be protected 
1
2 against discrimination.  Id. at 665.  In both instances, the Court concluded, the exercise of 
3
the right was protected by the Constitution.  Id. 
4
Wiley, supra, instructs that the states must ensure that the qualifications they impose 
5
6 for  voting  in  national  elections  mirrors  the  requisite  qualifications  implicitly,  if  not 
7
explicitly, required by the National Constitution.  Wiley, 179 U.S. at 64.  Thus, the right to 
8
vote in national elections is fundamentally based on the Constitution, and the Constitution 
9
requires that the states guarantee those privileges and defend those rights that obtain 
10
11
uniquely from national citizenship.  Id.  
12
More specifically, the Court described the privilege as a fundamental constitutional 
13
right preservative of all others.  Yick Wo v. Hopkins, 118 U.S. 356, 370, 6 S. Ct. 1064, 
14
15 1071, 30 L.Ed. 220, 226 (1886).  As the Court later confirmed, an infringement upon this 
16
right occurs where a legal citizens vote is diluted or nullified.  This nullification of an 
17
individual choice occurs whenever any illegitimate vote is cast, whether it be by a non-
18
19 citizen, a non-registered, or a non-existent voter. Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 565; 
20
84 S. Ct. 1362, 1383; 12 L.Ed.2d 506 (1964) (each citizen [has] an equally effective voice 
21
in the election  and the Constitution demands, no less.).   
22
Thus, a citizens right to a vote free of arbitrary impairment by state action has been 
23
24
judicially recognized as a right secured by the Constitution, when such impairment resulted 
25
from dilution by a false tally, cf. United States v. Classic, 313 U.S. 299, 314-15; 61 S. Ct. 
26
1031; 85 L.Ed. 1368 (1941); or by a refusal to count votes from arbitrarily selected 
27
28 precincts, cf. United States v. Mosley, 238 U.S. 383, 386-88; 35 S. Ct. 904; 59 L.Ed. 1355 
6 
 

 
(1915); or by a stuffing of the ballot box, cf. Ex parte Siebold, 100 U.S. 371, 388; 25 L.Ed. 
1
2 717 (1879); United States v. Saylor, 322 U.S. 385, 389; 64 S. Ct. 1101; 88 L.Ed. 1341 
3
(1944).  See also, Baker v. Carr, 369 U.S. 186, 208; 82 S. Ct. 691; 7 L.Ed.2d 663 (1962)  
4
As the Court has stated when discussing the privileges of citizenship, a new citizens 
5
6 right to vote and to participate in the democratic decision-making process is the honorable 
7
prerogative which no alien has a constitutional right to enjoy.  Foley v. Connelie, 435 U.S. 
8
291, 311; 98 S. Ct. 1067; 55 L.Ed.2d 287 (1978).  Therefore, it is clear that a State may 
9
deny aliens the right to vote; and the right to participate in the making of policy.  Id. 
10
11
at 291, 296-97.  These principles lie at the heart of our political institutions.  Id. at 291, 
12
citing Sugarman v. Dougall, 413 U.S. 634, 647; 93 S. Ct. 2842; 37 L.Ed.2d 853 (1973).   
13
Thus, the affirmative protections that the state may afford by way of statutes 
14
15 requiring proof of citizenship to vote must be considered in light of the implied protections 
16
afforded by the Constitution to all citizens by virtue of their status as such.  It is no more 
17
an affront to the fundamental constitutional rights of citizens that their vote is cancelled or 
18
19 nullified by the casting of a fraudulent vote, than by a vote that is cast by someone who 
20
does not possess the privilege.  Baker, supra (recognizing that an important badge of 
21
citizenship is the right to vote.).  Obviously, if a non-citizen exercises this right, it removes 
22
this privilege from citizens and dilutes their choice.  Thus, States may define and regulate 
23
24
the qualifications of its voters, and there is nothing in the Constitution that would prohibit 
25
the State from affirming by positive law that which is implicitly acknowledged in the 
26
Constitution. 
27
28
7 
 

 
For an added measure of assurance, it is declared that [t]he enumeration in the 
1
2 Constitution, of certain rights, shall not be construed to deny or disparage others retained 
3
by the people.  U.S. Const. Amend. 9.  It was universally agreed by the Framers that there 
4
are additional fundamental rights, protected from governmental infringement, which exist 
5
6 alongside those specifically mentioned in the first eight amendments.  I Annals of Congress 
7
439 (Gales and Seaton ed. 1834).  See also II Story, Commentaries on the Constitution of 
8
the United States (5th ed. 1891), pp. 626-627.  The [Ninth] Amendmentwas proffered 
9
to quiet expressed fears that a bill of specifically enumerated rights could not be sufficiently 
10
11
broad to cover all essential rights and that the specific mention of certain rights would be 
12
interpreted as a denial that others were protected.  Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. (1 Cranch) 
13
137, 174 (1803).  See also Myers v. United States, 272 U.S. 52, 229; 47 S. Ct. 21, 63 (1926). 
14
15 As it cannot be presumed that any clause in the constitution is intended to be 
16
without effecteffect should be given to all the words it uses.  United Pub. Workers v. 
17
Mitchell, 330 U.S. 75, 94-96; 67 S. Ct. 556 (1947).  And, indeed, a right to political 
18
19 affiliation and political choice has been addressed as protected, at least in part, by this 
20
amendment.   This includes, of course, the fundamental right to vote.   Id.  See also 
21
Reynolds, 377 U.S. at 560. 
22
That the latter is the fundamental and primary right among all other fundamental 
23
24
rights, enumerated or not, is evident in the fact it is self-executing.  Infringement upon it 
25
cannot occur under the Constitution if the government is, in fact, one that is duly and legally 
26
chosen by the People.  Any government that asserts a federal mandate to rule on the basis 
27
28
8 
 

 
of fraud or illegality effectuates an instant infringement on the sovereigns will, and, of 
1
2 necessity, has no legitimacy. 
3
II.  STATES  HAVE  A  COMPELLING  INTEREST  IN  PROTECTING 
4 VOTER INTEGRITY AND PREVENTING DILUTION OF CITIZEN 
VOTES 
5
 
6 A State indisputably has a compelling interest in preserving the integrity of its 
7
election process.  Purcell v. Gonzalez, 549 U.S. 1, 4; 127 S. Ct. 5; 166 L. Ed. 2d 1 (2006), 
8
citing Eu v. San Francisco County Democratic Central Comm., 489 U.S. 214, 231; 109 
9
S.Ct. 1013; 103 L.Ed.2d 271 (1989).  Confidence in the integrity of our electoral processes 
10
11
is essential to the functioning of our participatory democracy.  Voter fraud drives honest 
12
citizens out of the democratic process and breeds distrust of our government.  Voters who 
13
fear their legitimate votes will be outweighed by fraudulent ones will feel disenfranchised. 
14
15 [T]he right of suffrage can be denied by a debasement or dilution of the weight of a 
16
citizen's vote just as effectively as by wholly prohibiting the free exercise of the franchise. 
17
Reynolds, 377 U.S. at 555.  Countering the States compelling interest in preventing voter 
18
19 fraud is the plaintiffs strong interest in exercising the fundamental political right to vote. 
20
Dunn v. Blumstein, 405 U.S. 330, 336, 92 S.Ct. 995, 31 L.Ed.2d 274 (1972) (internal 
21
quotation marks omitted). Id. 
22
In Reynolds, 377 U.S. at 554-55, the Court held that the right of suffrage can be 
23
24
denied by a debasement or dilution of the weight of a citizens vote just as effectively as 
25
by wholly prohibiting the free exercise of the franchise. Purcell, supra.  Indeed, the right 
26
to have ones vote counted is as open to protection . . . as the right to put a ballot in a box. 
27
28 Mosley, 238 U.S. at 386. See also Baker, 369 U.S. at 208 (explaining that voters have a 
9 
 

 
plain, direct and adequate interest in  maintaining  the  effectiveness of their  votes.) 
1
2 (internal quotation marks omitted); Reynolds, supra at 567 (explaining that vote dilution 
3
occurs when [a]n individuals right to vote . . . is unconstitutionally impaired [because] 
4
its weight is in a substantial fashion diluted [] compared with the votes of citizens in other 
5
6 parts of the State.). 
7
One strong and entirely legitimate state interest is the prevention of fraud. Fraud 
8
can affect the outcome of a close election, and fraudulent votes dilute the right of citizens 
9
to cast ballots that carry appropriate weight. Fraud can also undermine public confidence 
10
11
in the fairness of elections and the perceived legitimacy of the announced outcome. 
12
Brnovich v. Democratic Natl Comm., 210 L. Ed. 2d 753, 141 S. Ct. 2321, 2340 (2021); 
13
Gonzalez v. Arizona, 677 F.3d 383, 403 (9th Cir. 2012), affd sub nom.  Arizona v. Inter 
14
15 Tribal Council of Arizona, Inc., 570 U.S. 1, 133 S. Ct. 2247, 186 L. Ed. 2d 239 (2013) 
16
( We recognize Arizonas concern about fraudulent voter registration.). 
17
A democratic country permits only its citizens of that country with the right to vote.  
18
19 Representative democracy in any populous unit of governance is unimaginable without 
20
the ability of citizens to band together in promoting among the electorate candidates who 
21
espouse their political views.  California Democratic Party v. Jones, 530 U.S. 567, 574, 
22
120 S. Ct. 2402, 2408, 147 L. Ed. 2d 502 (2000) (emphasis added).  Allowing non-citizen 
23
24
participation in Arizonas electoral process significantly undermines voters confidence in 
25
the  integrity  of  our  elections  and  discourages  voters  from  participating  because  of 
26
legitimate fears of vote dilution.  Both of these problems raise compelling state interests 
27
28 that the State of Arizona has the absolute and unrestrained right to protect. 
10 
 

 
Indeed, the problem of non-citizen participation in the democratic electoral and 
1
2 legal processes reserved for citizens is not an abstract one: A 2005 Report from the 
3
Government Accountability Office found that up to three (3%) percent of the 30,000 
4
individuals chosen for jury duty from voter registration rolls in just one U.S. district court 
5
6 over  a  two-year  period  were  not  U.S.  citizens.  Government  Accountability  Office, 
7
Elections:  Additional  Data  Could  Help  State  and  Local  Election  Officials  Maintain 
8
Accurate  Voter  Registration  Lists  42  (2005),  available  at 
9
www.gao.gov/assets/250/246628.pdf. According to a separate study released in 2014 by 
10
11
several  professors  at  Old  Dominion  University  and  George  Mason  University, 
12
approximately 6.4% of noncitizens voted in 2008 and 2.2% of noncitizens voted in 2010. 
13
Jesse T. Richman, Gulshan A. Chattha, and David C. Earnest, Do noncitizens vote in U.S. 
14
15 elections? Electoral Studies 36 (2014) 149-157. The Arizona Legislature therefore acted 
16
well within its constitutional role and consistent with its affirmative to duty to secure the 
17
purity of elections and guard against abuses of the elective franchise in enacting HB 2243 
18
19 and HB 2492 which will further strengthen the longstanding prohibition of non-citizen 
20
participation in Arizonas electoral process.  
21
CONCLUSION 
22
Article I, Section 4, of the U.S. Constitution is clear that election law is delegated 
23
24
to the States. Both the U.S. Constitution and the Constitution of Arizona clearly state that 
25
only U.S. citizens are permitted to vote in elections. Further, the State of Arizonas 
26
Legislature properly enacted HB 2243 and HB 2492 that requires proof of U.S. citizenship 
27
28 in order to register to vote, regardless of whether a prospective voter used the federal form 
11 
 

 
or Arizonas voter registration form. By requiring proof of citizenship, HB 2243 and HB 
1
2 2492 do not violate Section 6 of the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, section 7 
3
(NVRA or the Act), 52 U.S.C.  20505.  As the late Justice Scalia noted in Inter Tribal 
4
Council, supra at 17, that while the Elections Clause of the Constitution, Art. I,  4, cl. 1, 
5
6 empowers Congress to regulate how federal elections are held, it does not regulate who 
7
may vote in them - the latter is left to the sole province of the States.  Justice Thomas, in 
8
his dissent, agreed, noting that, The Framers did not intend to leave voter qualifications 
9
to Congress [] Congressional legislation of voter qualifications was not part of the 
10
11
Framers' design. Id. at 26. Justice Alito, in his dissent, concluded that, Indeed, even if 
12
neither the presumption against pre-emption nor the canon of constitutional avoidance 
13
applied, the better reading of the Act would be that Arizona is free to require those who 
14
15 use the federal form to supplement their applications with proof of citizenship. Id. at 44. 
16
The NVRA is nothing more than an optional form narrowly tailored so that is does 
17
not violate the United States Constitution for each States legislature to determine their 
18
19 own election laws. See U.S. Const. Art. I, 4. (each State by the Legislature thereof) 
20
Therefore, the States have full authority to enact election laws to protect voter integrity.  
21
Nowhere does the NVRA expressly prohibit the States from requiring voter proof of 
22
citizenship, and in fact it could not do. See Inter Tribal Council, supra. 
23
24  
25
  For the forgoing reasons, and those stated in Defendants Consolidated Motion to 
26
Dismiss, the Motion to Dismiss should be granted.  
27
28
12 
 

 
1   Respectfully submitted, this 23rd day of September, 2022. 
2  
3  
  /s/ Michael Ryan Williams 
4
MICHAEL RYAN WILLIAMS, ESQ. 
5   3636 North Central Avenue 
Phoenix, Arizona 85012

  (602) 740-0321 
8
 
9   CARSON J. TUCKER, ESQ. 
Lex Fori, PLLC 
10
DPT #3020 
11 1250 West 14 Mile Road 
Troy, Michigan 48083-1030 
12
cjtucker@lexfori.org 
 
13
LORRAINE G. WOODWARK, ESQ. 
14
Attorneys United for a Secure America 
(AUSA) 
15
25 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Ste 335 
16 Washington, D.C. 20001 
LWoodwark@IRLI.org  
17
(202) 591-0962 
18  
Counsel for Amicus Curiae 
19
Advocates for Victims of Illegal Alien 
20 Crime (AVIAC) 
   
21

13 
 

 
   
1
2 CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE 
3
  1. This brief has been prepared using 14-point, proportionately spaced, serif 
4
typeface, in Microsoft Word. 
5
6 2. This brief complies with FED. R. APP. P. 29(a)(5) and 32(a)(7)(B) because it 
7 contains a total of 4619 words, excluding material not counted under Rule 32(f). 
8
 
9
Respectfully submitted, this 23rd day of September, 2022. 
10
11

    3636 North Central Avenue

    Phoenix, Arizona 85012

    (602) 740-0321

Lead Counsel for Movant AVIAC

2 I hereby certify that on this 23rd day of September, 2022, I electronically filed the 
3 foregoing motiontogether with the accompanying Corporate Disclosure Statement, 
4 Proposed Order, and Memorandum of Lawwith the Clerk using the CM/ECF system, 
5 which I understand to have served the parties counsel who are registered in as CM/ECF 
6 users.

documents.title: Opposition to Immigration Reform Law Institute's and Advocates for Victims of Illegal Alien Crime's Motions for Leave to File Briefs of Amicus Curiae in Support of Defendants' Consolidated Motion to Dismiss
documents.text:
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 134   Filed 09/26/22   Page 1 of 7
 
1   
Daniel J. Adelman (011368)   Jon Sherman (DC Bar No. 998271) 
2  Arizona Center for Law     Michelle Kanter Cohen (DC Bar No. 989164) 
In the Public Interest  Cecilia Aguilera (DC Bar No. 1617884) 
3  352 E. Camelback Rd., #200  Fair Elections Center 
Phoenix, AZ  85012  1825 K St. NW, Ste. 450 
4  (602) 258-8850  Washington, D.C. 20006 
danny@aclpi.org    (202) 331-0114 
5    jsherman@fairelectionscenter.org 
  mkantercohen@fairelectionscenter.org  
6     caguilera@fairelectionscenter.org  
 
7  John A. Freedman  Steven L. Mayer  
Jeremy Karpatkin  Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer LLP 
8

Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer LLP  San Francisco, CA  94111
