Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 3 of 22
 
11   Plaintiff Mi Familia Vota, by and through its undersigned attorneys, files this 
22   Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief against Defendants Katie Hobbs, in her 
33   official capacity as the Secretary of State of Arizona, Mark Brnovich, in his official 
44   capacity as the Attorney General of Arizona, and the above-captioned County Recorder 
Defendants,  each  named  in  their  official  capacities.  In  support,  Plaintiff  alleges  the 
55  
following: 
66  
NATURE OF THE CASE 
77  
1.  This  is  an  action  brought  under  the  U.S.  Constitution  to  safeguard  the 
88  
fundamental rights of hundreds of thousands of Arizonans, including the right to vote and 
99  
the state-protected right to vote early by mail, which are subject to due process protections. 
1100  
No right is more precious in a free country than that of having a voice in the election of 
1111  
those who make the laws under which, as good citizens, we must live. Other rights, even 
1122  
the most basic, are illusory if the right to vote is undermined. Wesberry v. Sanders, 376 
1133  
U.S. 1, 17 (1964). In this action, Plaintiff challenges Arizonas latest effort to undermine 
1144  
that most precious right: the recently enacted H.B. 2492, which severely burdens the right 
1155   to vote and, in many cases, will deny that right entirely, disenfranchising eligible, lawful 
1166   voters in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.  
1177   2.  Arizona has a long and complex history of applying different registration and 
1188   voting requirements to different voters, which has caused portions of its law to be held in 
violation of federal law and has required the State to enter into an ongoing consent decree. 
1199  
See Arizona v. Inter Tribal Council of Ariz., Inc., 570 U.S. 1, 15 (2013); Consent Decree 
2200  
at  7-16,  LULAC  v.  Reagan,  No.  2:17-cv-04102-DGC  (June  18,  2018),  ECF  No.  37 
2211  
(Consent Decree). The result is a byzantine system in which Arizona has three classes of 
2222  
voters: (1) those who registered pre-2005 and did not have to show documentary proof of 
2233  
citizenship (because Arizona did not yet require it), who can vote in all elections; (2) those 
2244  
who  registered  post-2005  using  the  federal  form  required  by  the  National  Voter 
2255  
Registration Act (NVRA) (the Federal Form) and did not show documentary proof of 
2266  
citizenship, who can vote only in federal elections; and (3) those who registered post-2005 
2277  
and showed adequate proof of citizenship, who can vote in all elections. All of these voters 
2288  
are entitled to vote in elections for which they are qualified by mail, a right which Arizona 
  
-1- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 4 of 22
 
11   has provided to all voters for any reason since 1991. See A.R.S.  16-541. Further, under 
22   the ongoing consent decree, the state must (1) treat all registrants the same regardless of 
33   whether they use the state form or Federal Form, registering all voters for federal elections 
44   regardless of provided evidence of citizenship; and (2) check the motor vehicles database 
for citizenship documentation before limiting voters to federal-only elections. See Consent 
55  
Decree at 7-16. 
66  
3.  H.B. 2492 (the Proof of Citizenship Restriction), which was signed into 
77  
law on March 30, 2022, adds another confusing, discriminatory, and unconstitutional 
88  
impediment to this morass. Among other things, the Restriction will require new registrants 
99  
using the Federal Form to provide additional documentation if they want to vote in 
1100  
presidential  elections  or  vote  early  by  mail  for  any  office,  prohibit  those  currently 
1111  
registered using the Federal Form who registered without proof of citizenship from voting 
1122  
by mail or in presidential elections, and require long-registered Arizonans who never had 
1133  
to provide proof of citizenshipestimated to be close to 200,000 voters1to locate and 
1144  
present additional documentation to vote in presidential elections. The law provides no 
1155   details concerning how long-registered voters will be notified that they must provide new 
1166   documents, or how they will be given an opportunity to do so, and also requires the 
1177   Attorney General to investigate and potentially prosecute voters who registered without 
1188   providing proof of citizenship. 
4.  The  Proof  of  Citizenship  Restriction  continues  a  baseless  assault  on 
1199  
Arizonas election system based on a conspiracy theory that non-citizens are voting, despite 
2200  
a persistent lack of credible evidence to support such claims. The Restriction is the newest 
2211  
in a series of cynical and bad faith attempts to use these politically motivated and false 
2222  
allegations to limit access to voting by eligible, lawful citizens. And the new laws 
2233  
limitations on early voting are particularly pernicious given the prevalence of early voting 
2244  
by mail in Arizona. In 2020, a record-setting 88 percent of voters used Arizonas early 
2255  
2266    
1 See Laurie Roberts, Republicans want HOW MANY Arizonans to prove they have a right 
2277  
to  vote?,  The  Ariz.  Republic  (March  28,  2022,  9:12  AM), 
https://www.azcentral.com/story/opinion/op-ed/laurieroberts/2022/03/28/arizona-voters-
2288  
may-soon-prove-right-vote-citizenship/7192260001/. 
  
-2- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 5 of 22
 
11   voting by mail system to cast their ballots. But, even before the pandemic, early voting was 
22   the most common form of voting in the state. In 2016, over 2 million Arizona votersor 
33   about 75 percent of those who participated in the electionused early voting. Even in 
44   2008, more than a million votersor close to half of those participatingused early 
voting. And, as more voters have turned to early voting by mail, Arizonas election 
55  
administrators have responded by diverting their resources to support mail-in voting, 
66  
anticipating that the overwhelming majority of Arizona voters will exercise their right to 
77  
vote by mail. As a result, in-person voting facilities and opportunities have dramatically 
88  
decreased.  
99  
5.  In other words, for decades Arizonas voting system has been oriented 
1100  
toward  supporting  and  facilitating  early  mail  voters.  It  was  well-tested  and  well-
1111  
established. There is no evidence that it was undermined or even vulnerable to abuse or 
1122  
fraud. Quite to the contrary, both Governor Doug Ducey and Secretary Hobbs have 
1133  
repeatedly assured the public and the nation that false claims about the legitimacy of 
1144  
Arizonas 2020 election are to be rejected, that the election was secure and fraud-free, and 
1155   that the results should be trusted. As Governor Ducey emphasized in response to attacks 
1166   on the integrity of the 2020 election: Weve been doing early voting since 1992, and 
1177   claims about problems with the system or the election are unfounded.2 Despite these 
1188   assurances,  multiple  lawsuits  and  contests  brought  by  the  Republican  Party,  former 
President Donald Trumps campaign, and their supporters have sought to cast doubt on the 
1199  
outcome of the 2020 election. Arizonas state and federal courts responded by rejecting 
2200  
those suits and repudiated their champions for their striking lack of evidence. For example, 
2211  
in a case brought by the Arizona Republican Party to challenge the legitimacy of Maricopa 
2222  
Countys audit, the Superior Court ordered the party to pay attorneys fees to the Secretary 
2233  
of State under A.R.S.  12-349 because the lawsuit was groundless, brought in bad 
2244  
faith, and served only to cast false shadows on the elections legitimacy. Order at 9-10, 
2255  
Ariz. Republican Party v. Fontes, No. CV 2020-014553, (Mar. 12, 2021). 
2266  
6.  The same false narratives sowed the groundwork for the Proof of Citizenship 
2277  
 
2 @DougDucey, Twitter (Nov. 30, 2020, 9:48 PM) 
2288  
https://twitter.com/dougducey/status/1333603891863191552? ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw. 
  
-3- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 6 of 22
 
11   Restriction, and now, as a result, tens of thousands of Arizonans will be forced to jump 
22   through unnecessary hoops to access the mail voting system upon which they have come 
33   to rely, and to vote in presidential elections whether by mail or in person. Some of those 
44   lawful,  eligible  Arizona  voters  will  be  unable  to  clear  the  Restrictions  hurdles.  As 
manifested by state officials full-throated defense of Arizonas election system in the 
55  
immediate aftermath of the November 2020 election, as well as multiple court decisions 
66  
related to the same, there are no state interests, much less compelling ones, to justify the 
77  
new imposition of these unjustifiable and disparate burdens. There is no evidence that any 
88  
of Arizonas voting methods are beset by fraud, and no credible evidence that non-citizens 
99  
are attempting to overcome (much less actually overcoming) the numerous safeguards 
1100  
Arizona has put in place to limit voting in Arizona to United States citizens. The Proof of 
1111  
Citizenship Restriction is an entirely illegitimate and unconstitutional roadblock erected in 
1122  
the path of lawful, eligible voters. For these reasons and those detailed below, Plaintiff 
1133  
respectfully  requests  a  declaration  that  the  Proof  of  Citizenship  Restriction  is 
1144  
unconstitutional and an order enjoining its enforcement. 
1155   JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
1166   7.  Plaintiff brings this action pursuant to 42 U.S.C.  1983 and 1988 to redress 
1177   the deprivation, under the color of state law, of their rights under the First and Fourteenth 
1188   Amendments to the U.S. Constitution. 
8.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction to hear Plaintiffs claims pursuant 
1199  
to 28 U.S.C.  1331, 1343, and 1357. 
2200  
9.  This Court has jurisdiction over the Secretary of State, as she is sued in her 
2211  
official capacity as an elected official in Arizona. Further, the Secretary works and resides 
2222  
in the State of Arizona.  
2233  
10.  This Court has jurisdiction over the Attorney General, as he is sued in his 
2244  
official capacity as an elected official in Arizona. Further, the Attorney General works and 
2255  
resides in the State of Arizona. 
2266  
11.  This Court has jurisdiction over the County Recorder Defendants, as they are 
2277  
sued in their official capacities as elected officials in Arizona, and they work or reside in 
2288  
the State of Arizona. 
  
-4- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 7 of 22
 
11   12.  Venue is proper under 28 U.S.C.  1391(b) because a substantial part of the 
22   events or omissions giving rise to the claims occurred in this judicial district and in this 
33   division. 
44   13.  This  Court  has  the  authority  to  grant  declaratory  and  injunctive  relief 
pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  2201 and 2202. Further, this Court has the authority to enter a 
55  
declaratory judgment and to provide preliminary and permanent injunctive relief pursuant 
66  
to Rules 57 and 65 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.  
77  
PARTIES 
88  
14.  Plaintiff Mi Familia Vota (MFV) is a national, non-profit civic engagement 
99  
organization with a mission of uniting Latino, immigrant, and allied communities to 
1100  
promote social and economic justice through increased civic participation by encouraging 
1111  
leadership development, citizenship, and issue organizing. MFV encourages non-partisan 
1122  
voter registration and voter participation and has challenged voter suppression around the 
1133  
nation. See, e.g., Mi Familia Vota v. Hobbs, No: 2:21-cv-01423-DWL (D. Ariz. filed Aug. 
1144  
17, 2021); Mi Familia Vota v. Abbott, 497 F. Supp. 3d 195 (W.D. Tex. 2020). It has 
1155   operations in six states, including Arizona, where it is headquartered. More than 14,000 
1166   Arizonans follow and engage with MFV via email and/or MFVs social media platforms. 
1177   15.  In advance of the 2020 election, MFV organized voter registration drives and 
1188   conducted get-out-the-vote activities. MFV helped countless Arizonans register to vote 
using a Federal Form and helped countless Arizonans register to vote by mail. MFV also 
1199  
conducted  voter  education  campaigns  and  provided  other  voter  assistance,  including 
2200  
driving voters to polling locations.  
2211  
16.  MFV plans to organize the same activities for future elections. As a result of 
2222  
the Proof of Citizenship Restriction, however, MFV must divert money, personnel, time, 
2233  
and resources away from other programming in order to dedicate more resources toward 
2244  
efforts  to  ensure  that  voters  can  navigate  the  restrictions  imposed  by  the  Proof  of 
2255  
Citizenship Restriction. Additionally, MFV plans to hire additional staff to help educate 
2266  
voters about the Proof of Citizenship Restriction and is considering developing public 
2277  
service announcements in Spanish-language media concerning the changes. MFV will also 
2288  
expend resources confirming that voters who previously registered to vote either (1) pre-
  
-5- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 8 of 22
 
11   2005 or (2) post-2005 using the Federal Form, are not prohibited from voting early by mail 
22   or in presidential elections due to the Proof of Citizenship Restriction.   
33   17.  Defendant Katie Hobbs is the Secretary of State of Arizona and is the Chief 
44   Elections Officer for Arizona. Ariz. Const. art. V,  9; A.R.S.  16-142. As Arizonas Chief 
Elections Officer, the Secretary is responsible for carrying out the states election laws and 
55  
overseeing the voting processand is empowered with broad authority to carry out that 
66  
responsibility. As such, the Secretary has the authority to promulgate rules and procedures 
77  
for elections, including rules and regulations pertaining to voter registration. A.R.S.  16-
88  
452, 16-168(J). Moreover, the Secretary is charged with enforcing the new statutory 
99  
provisions at issue here. A.R.S.  16-143. The Secretary is sued in her official capacity for 
1100  
actions taken under color of state law. 
1111  
18.  Defendant Mark Brnovich is the Attorney General of Arizona and the States 
1122  
chief  legal  officer.  A.R.S.  41-192.  The  Attorney  General  is  authorized  to  enforce 
1133  
Arizonas election laws in any election for state office, members of the legislature, justices 
1144  
of the supreme court, judges of the court of appeals or statewide initiative or referendum 
1155   . . . through civil and criminal actions. A.R.S.  16-1021. Moreover, the Attorney General 
1166   is charged with enforcing the new statutory provisions at issue here. A.R.S.  16-143. The 
1177   Attorney General is sued in his official capacity for actions taken under color of state law.   
1188   19.  The Proof of Citizenship Restriction makes county recorders responsible for 
implementing  and  enforcing  the  statutory  provisions  at  issue  here.  Amongst  other 
1199  
responsibilities, county recorders are charged with verifying a voters citizenship status, 
2200  
rejecting  voter  registration  applications  if  the  county  recorder  cannot  confirm  an 
2211  
applicants  citizenship  status,  forwarding  applications  to  the  Attorney  General  for 
2222  
investigation, and canceling a voters registration based on citizenship. See generally H.B. 
2233  
2492. The County Recorder Defendants listed below are sued in their official capacities for 
2244  
actions taken under color of state law. 
2255  
20.  Defendant Larry Noble is the Apache County Recorder.  
2266  
21.  Defendant David W. Stevens is the Cochise County. 
2277  
22.  Defendant Patty Hansen is the Coconino County Recorder. 
2288  
23.  Defendant Sadie Jo Bingham is the Gila County Recorder. 
  
-6- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 9 of 22
 
11   24.  Defendant Wendy John is the Graham County Recorder. 
22   25.  Defendant Sharie Milheiro is the Greenlee County.

1122  
Unjustifiable Burden on the Right to Vote  
1133   U.S. Const. Amend. I, XIV, 42 U.S.C.  1983 
(As to all Defendants) 
1144  
 
68.  Plaintiff realleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs 1 through 67 as 
1155  
if fully set forth herein. 
1166  
69.  A court considering a challenge to a state election law must carefully balance 
1177  
the character and magnitude of injury to the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights that 
1188  
the Plaintiff seeks to vindicate against the justifications put forward by the state for the 
1199  
burdens imposed by the rule. Burdick v. Takushi, 504 U.S. 428, 434 (1992); Anderson v. 
2200  
Celebrezze, 460 U.S. 780, 789 (1983).  
2211  
70.  However slight th[e] burden may appear, . . . it must be justified by relevant 
2222  
and legitimate state interests sufficiently weighty to justify the limitation. Crawford v. 
2233  
Marion  Cnty.  Election  Bd.,  553  U.S.  181,  191  (2008)  (Stevens,  J.,  controlling  op.) 
2244   (quotations marks omitted).  
2255   71.  The Proof of Citizenship Restriction imposes a disparate and unjustifiable 
2266   burden on the right to vote. As detailed above, it strips voters of the right to vote in 
2277   presidential elections or by mail without notice, adds further confusion to what was already 
a convoluted registration process that has led to disenfranchisement, imposes substantial 
2288  
  
-17- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 20 of 22
 
11   new costs on hundreds of thousands of Arizonans to exercise the franchise, and exposes 
22   voters to the threat of baseless investigation by the Attorney General. Both individually 
33   and in combination these harms impose a significantand in many cases severeburden 
44   on the right to vote. 
72.  These burdens are not justified by any sufficient state interest.  
55  
COUNT II 
66  
Denial of Procedural Due Process 
77  
U.S. Const. Amend. XIV, 42 U.S.C.  1983 
88   (As to all Defendants) 
 
99  
73.  Plaintiff realleges and reincorporates by reference paragraphs 1 through 72 
1100   as though fully set forth herein. 
1111   74.  To determine whether a plaintiff has been denied procedural due process in 
1122   violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, a court first asks 
1133   whether a constitutionally protected liberty interest is at stake. If so, the court determines 
whether the procedural protections provided are sufficient by applying the Anderson-
1144  
Burdick test as described above. Ariz. Democratic Party v. Hobbs, 18 F.4th 1179, 1195 
1155  
(9th Cir. 2021) (holding that the Anderson/Burdick approach is better suited to the context 
1166  
of election laws than is the more general Eldridge test (quoting Richardson v. Tex. Secy 
1177  
of State, 978 F.3d 220, 234 (5th Cir. 2020))).  
1188  
75.  The right to vote is a fundamental constitutional right. Harper v. Va. State 
1199  
Bd. of Elections, 383 U.S. 663, 667 (1966). Other rights, even the most basic, are illusory 
2200  
if the right to vote is undermined. Wesberry, 376 U.S. at 17. Because Arizona allows all 
2211  
registered voters to exercise their fundamental right to vote early by mail, there is a 
2222  
constitutionally protected liberty interest involved in the process of casting a ballot by mail 
2233  
and in having that ballot counted. See, e.g., Democracy N.C. v. N.C. State Bd. of Elections, 
2244   476  F.  Supp  3d  158,  227  (M.D.N.C.  2020)  (holding  that  North  Carolina,  having 
2255   authorized the use of absentee ballots, must afford appropriate due process protections to 
2266   the use of the absentee ballots); Martin v. Kemp, 341 F. Supp. 3d 1326, 1338 (N.D. Ga. 
2277   2018) (Courts around the country have recognized that [w]hile it is true that absentee 
voting is a privilege and a convenience to voters, this does not grant the state the latitude 
2288  
  
-18- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SMB   Document 1   Filed 03/31/22   Page 21 of 22
 
11   to deprive citizens of due process with respect to the exercise of this privilege.) (quoting 
22   Raetzel v. Parks/Bellemont Absentee Election Bd., 762 F. Supp. 1354, 1358 (D. Ariz. 
33   1990)); Zessar v. Helander, No. 05 C 1917, 2006 WL 642646, at *5 (N.D. Ill. Mar. 13, 
44   2006) (The right to vote by absentee ballot is not, in and of itself, a fundamental right. But 
once the State permits voters to vote absentee, it must afford appropriate due process 
55  
protections, including notice and a hearing, before rejecting an absentee ballot.). As a 
66  
result, Defendants may not deprive voters of the right to vote early by mail without 
77  
providing adequate procedures. 
88  
76.  Arizonas  Proof  of  Citizenship  Restriction  will  deprive  hundreds  of 
99  
thousands of currently registered voters of their ability to vote by mail in future elections. 
1100  
It does so while giving no details about any notice these voters will be provided, or how or 
1111  
when they may cure this defect. 
1122  
77.  As  detailed  above,  there  is  no  state  interest  which  justifies  stripping 
1133  
registered voters of the state-protected right to vote early by mail with no notice or 
1144  
opportunity to cure. 
1155   PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
1166   Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Court enter the following judgment: 
1177   A. Declare that the Proof of Citizenship Restriction (H.B. 2492) violates the First 
1188   and Fourteenth Amendments; 
B. Enjoin Defendants, along with their respective agents, officers, employees, and 
1199  
successors from enforcing the Proof of Citizenship Restriction; 
2200  
C. Award Plaintiff its costs, expenses, and reasonable attorneys fees, pursuant to 
2211  
42 U.S.C.  1988, and any other applicable law; 
2222  
D. Grant such other and further relief as the Court deems just and proper. 
2233  
 
2244  
 
2255  
 
2266  
 
2277  
 
2288  
  
-19- 
PLAINTIFFS COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF

documents.text:
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 1 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  CAMPAIGN LEGAL CENTER  
Danielle Lang* 
2  Jonathan Diaz* 
Molly Danahy* 
3  Hayden Johnson* 
1101 14th St. NW, Suite 400  
4  Washington, D.C. 20005 
(202) 736-2200

hjohnson@campaignlegalcenter.org

BARTON MENDEZ SOTO PLLC  
8  James Barton, AZ Bar No. 023888  
401 W. Baseline Road, Suite 205 
9  Tempe, AZ 85283  
480-418-0668  
10  james@bartonmendezsoto.com  
 
Attorneys for Plaintiffs 
11 
Additional counsel listed on last page 
*admitted pro hac vice 
12 
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
13 
 
   
14 
MI FAMILIA VOTA et al.,   
   
15 
Plaintiffs   
   
16 
v.   
  Case No. 2:22-cv-00509 (Lead Case) 
17  KATIE HOBBS, in her official capacity as 
Secretary of State for Arizona, et al.,    Judge Susan R. Bolton 
18   
Defendants   
 
19 
MARK BRNOVICH, in his official capacity 
as Attorney General of Arizona, et al.,  
20 
 
Intervenor Defendants 
21 
 
 
22 
  1 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 2 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  LIVING UNITED FOR CHANGE IN   
ARIZONA, LEAGUE OF UNITED LATIN   
2  ALERICAN CITIZENS, ARIZONA   
STUDENTS ASSOCIATION; ADRC   
ACTION, INTER TRIBAL COUNCIL OF   
3 
ARIZONA, INC., SAN CARLOS APACHE   
TRIBE, a federally-recognized tribe,   
4 
ARIZONA COALITION FOR CHANGE,    
   
5 
Plaintiffs,  Case No. 2:22-cv-00519 (Consolidated Case) 
 
6 
v.  Judge Susan R. Bolton 
 
7  KATIE HOBBS, in her official capacity as  FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR 
Secretary of State of Arizona;  DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE 
8    RELIEF 
Defendant, 
 
9 
MARK BRNOVICH, in his official capacity 
as Attorney General of Arizona; STATE OF 
10 
ARIZONA, 
 
11 
Intervenor Defendants. 
 
12 
LUCHA PLAINTIFFS FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT 
 
13  1.  In 2022, the Arizona Legislature enacted and Governor Doug Ducey of Arizona 
14  signed into law two bills, House Bill 2492 (HB 2492) and House Bill 2243 (HB 2243), that 
impose a host of arbitrary and discriminatory burdens on eligible Arizona voters in violation of 
15 
the  United  States  Constitution,  the  Civil  Rights  Act  of  1964  (CRA),  the  National  Voter 
16 
Registration Act (NVRA), and the Voting Rights Act of 1965.  
17 
2.  HB 2492 was adopted in explicit defiance of federal law and the United States 
18 
Constitution. After nonpartisan legal staff advised the Arizona legislature that the bill would likely 
19 
violate federal law, one of the bills proponents expressly acknowledged that defiance is a purpose 
20 
of HB 2492. 
21 
22 
  2 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 3 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  3.  Among other violative provisions, HB2492 requires that eligible Arizonans provide 
2  documentary proof of citizenship and residence in order to register to vote; requires that election 
officials reject the registration applications of Arizonans who do provide documentary proof of 
3 
citizenship if they fail to check a box on the voter registration application, or if they fail to provide 
4 
their place of birth on their application; and conditions an applicants right to vote on the seemingly 
5 
inconsequential choice of whether to use a state versus a federal voter registration form. These 
6 
arbitrary, burdensome, and immaterial barriers to registering to vote are directly at odds with 
7 
federal law.  
8 
4.  In addition, HB 2492 denies certain Arizonansthose who are unable to provide 
9 
documentary proof of citizenship but are entitled to register and vote in federal electionsthe right 
10 
to vote on an equal basis with all other Arizona voters by prohibiting these Federal-only voters 
11 
from voting by mail. 
12  5.  In an extraordinary step that defies any conception of popular sovereignty, HB 2492 
13  also denies eligible Federal-only voters their equal right to vote for the President of the United 
14  States.  
6.  No other state in the nation has abridged the fundamental right to vote for eligible 
15 
voters in a such a manner.  
16 
7.  HB 2492 discriminates against Native American voters from tribes located in 
17 
Arizona by imposing a proof of residential address requirement for voter registration that will 
18 
prohibit many Native voters living on reservations from registering to vote, despite an existing 
19 
stipulation providing accommodations for such voters with respect to the same requirement under 
20 
Arizonas voter ID law. 
21 
22 
  3 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 4 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  8.   Finally, HB 2492 and HB 2243 intentionally discriminate against naturalized U.S. 
2  citizens, Latinos, and members of language minority communities by (i) subjecting them to 
heightened  burdens  to  register  and  vote;  (ii)  mandating  that  elected  officials  reject  voter 
3 
registration applications and purge registered voters from the registration rolls based on outdated 
4 
and incorrect U.S. citizenship data derived from unreliable sources; (iii) subjecting eligible voters 
5 
to  harassment,  criminal  investigation;  and  (iv)  prosecution  by  Intervenor-Defendant  Mark 
6 
Brnovich, and singling out naturalized U.S. citizens for harassment based on their place of birth
7 
a fact that has no bearing on their eligibility to vote.  
8 
9.  Plaintiffs Living United for Change in Arizona (LUCHA), League of United 
9 
Latin American Citizens (LULAC), Arizona Students Association (ASA), ADRC Action 
10 
(ADRC), Inter Tribal Council of Arizona, Inc. (ITCA), the San Carlos Apache Tribe, and the 
11 
Arizona Coalition for Change (AZC4C) bring this Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive 
12  Relief to remedy the violations alleged herein. 
13  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
 
14  10.  This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  1331 and 1343, 
42 U.S.C.  1983, and 52 U.S.C.  10301, et seq. 
15 
11.  This Court also has jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  1362, which provides that 
16 
district courts shall have original jurisdiction of all civil actions, brought by any Indian tribe or 
17 
band with a governing body duly recognized by the Secretary of the Interior, wherein the matter 
18 
in controversy arises under the Constitution, laws, or treaties of the United States. 
19 
12.  This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant Secretary of State Hobbs and 
20 
Intervenor-Defendant Attorney General Mark Brnovich, elected constitutional officers for and 
21 
residents of the State of Arizona. 
22 
  4 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 5 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  13.  Intervenor-Defendant the State of Arizona has waived sovereign immunity and 
2  submitted to the jurisdiction of this Court by voluntarily intervening to defend this action. Clark 
v. Barnard, 108 U.S. 436, 447 (1883). 
3 
14.  Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  1391. 
4 
15.  This Court has authority to issue declaratory and injunctive relief pursuant to 28 
5 
U.S.C.  2201 and 2202. 
6 
FACTUAL AND LEGAL BACKGROUND 
7   
16.  On March 30, 2022, Governor Ducey signed into law House Bill 2492 (HB 
8 
2492). 
9 
17.  On April 22, 2022, Governor Ducey signed Senate Bill 1638, which made a 
10 
technical amendment to one section of HB 2492 and delayed the effective date for all of HB 2492s 
11 
provisions to December 31, 2022.  
12  18.  On June 23, 2022, the Arizona Legislature passed House Bill 2243 (HB 2243), 
13  which was signed into law by Governor Ducey on July 6, 2022. 
14  19.  HB 2243s provisions will become effective September 24, 2022. 
Documentary Proof of Residence Requirement 
15 
20.  HB 2492 violates federal law by requiring that eligible Arizona voters, with narrow 
16 
exceptions for qualified individuals temporarily absent from the State, provide documentary proof 
17 
of residence (DPOR) to register to vote in any election.  
18 
21.  DPOR is defined as an identifying document that establishes proof of location of 
19 
residence. HB 2492  5 (to be codified at A.R.S.  16-123). Under HB 2492, a valid and 
20 
unexpired Arizona Driver License or nonoperating identification number that is properly verified 
21 
by the county recorder satisfies the requirements of this section. Id.  
22 
  5 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 6 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  22.  In addition, HB 2492 states that any of the identifying documents required for 
2  identification while voting under A.R.S.  16-579(A)(1) constitutes satisfactory proof of location 
of residence. HB 2492  5 (to be codified at A.R.S.  16-123). Those documents are:  
3 
(a) A valid form of identification that bears the photograph, name and address of 
4 
the elector that reasonably appear to be the same as the name and address in the 
precinct register, including an Arizona driver license, an Arizona nonoperating 
5 
identification license, a tribal enrollment card or other form of tribal identification 
or  a  United  States  federal,  state  or  local  government  issued  identification. 
6  Identification is deemed valid unless it can be determined on its face that it has 
expired. 
7   
(b) Two different items that contain the name and address of the elector that 
8  reasonably appear to be the same as the name and address in the precinct register, 
including a utility bill, a bank or credit union statement that is dated within ninety 
days of the date of the election, a valid Arizona vehicle registration, an Arizona 
9 
vehicle insurance card, an Indian census card, tribal enrollment card or other form 
of tribal identification, a property tax statement, a recorders certificate, a voter 
10 
registration card, a valid United States federal, state or local government issued 
identification  or  any  mailing  that  is  labeled  as  official  election  material. 
11 
Identification is deemed valid unless it can be determined on its face that it has 
expired. 
12   
(c) A valid form of identification that bears the photograph, name and address of 
13  the elector except that if the address on the identification does not reasonably appear 
to be the same as the address in the precinct register or the identification is a valid 
14  United States military identification card or a valid United States passport and does 
not bear an address, the identification must be accompanied by one of the items 
listed in subdivision (b) of this paragraph. 
15 
 
A.R.S.  16-579(A)(1). 
16 
 
23.  All voters in Arizona registering to vote must attest to their legal residence under 
17 
the penalty of perjury. And under existing law, the above documentation of residence is already 
18 
provided at the time of voting in person (subject to a stipulation providing for voting access for 
19 
Native voters).  
20 
24.  HB 2492s DPOR Requirement imposes new and duplicative burdens on voters to 
21 
access or obtain, copy, print, and submit the required documents at the time they register.  
22 
  6 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 7 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  25.  The DPOR Requirement will most affect Arizonans who lack a valid Arizona 
2  drivers license or nonoperating state-ID card and will have a more difficult time accessing and 
providing the documentation to prove their residence. These disparately burdened Arizonans 
3 
include low-income voters, college and university students, enrolled members of Arizona tribes, 
4 
and voters who frequently move, many of whom for circumstances largely beyond their control, 
5 
such as employment, family and school demands.  
6 
26.  Further, the DPOR Requirement may effectively bar eligible voters who live in a 
7 
residence without a numbered street address from registering to vote because these registrants lack 
8 
any documents containing their nonexistent residential address.  
9 
27.  In recognition of the substantial number of eligible voters whose residence does not 
10 
have a numbered street address, the State of Arizona permits registrants to include a description 
11 
and drawing of their place of residence on their voter application form, rather than a numbered 
12  street address.1 
13  28.  However, HB 2492 contains no exceptions to the DPOR Requirement for these 
14  eligible voters without a numbered street address. 
29.  Because many residences on Indian reservations in Arizona lack a numbered street 
15 
address or residential address, many enrolled members of tribes are likely to be prevented from 
16 
voting by the DPOR Requirement. 
17 
30.  For example, on the San Carlos Apache Reservation, where Plaintiff San Carlos 
18 
Apache Tribe is located, there is not a uniform residential numbering system for physical addresses 
19 
that identifies residences by a street address or residence or building number.   
20 
 
21 
 
1  See  Arizona  Secretary  of  State,  Arizona  Voter  Registration  Form  (Jan.  2022), 
22  https://azsos.gov/sites/default/files/2022_Voter_Registration_Form.pdf. 
  7 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 8 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  31.  For example, there are at least 100 residential or access roads that lead to residences, 
2  located on the south side of U.S. Route 70, which connects Ft. Thomas to Globe, Arizona, that 
have no names or route number.  
3 
32.  Accordingly, many residences are not assigned a physical numbered street address. 
4 
Instead, members of the Tribe commonly describe where they live using common road names, 
5 
mile markers on Route 70, Bureau of Indian Affairs Indian Routes, or other landmarks and 
6 
distances.  
7 
33.  For example, one resident of the Reservation would refer to his home as located on 
8 
the south side of Route 70, just outside and several miles west the community of Peridot, near mile 
9 
marker 268, and then 300 yards down that dirt road. 
10 
34.  For this reason, the Tribes enrolled members living on the Reservation commonly 
11 
receive mail at post office boxes located on or near the Reservation. 
12  35.  Because many homes on the San Carlos Apache Reservation do not have numbered 
13  street addresses, the Tribes members who live on the Reservation often do not have documents 
14  listing  their  name  and  residential  address,  and  thus  will  be  unable  to  satisfy  the  DPOR 
Requirement. 
15 
36.  By  not  satisfying  that  Requirement,  such  members  would  effectively  be 
16 
disenfranchised. 
17 
37.  In addition to the San Carlos Apache Tribe, other ITCA Member Tribes also have 
18 
large and rural reservations, and their members commonly lack the type of documentation required 
19 
by HB 2492. Many members of these tribes similarly lack the documentation mandated by the 
20 
DPOR Requirement and will therefore be barred from voting by HB 2492. 
21 
22 
  8 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 9 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  38.  The experience for citizens of the San Carlos Apache is also the norm for many 
2  other Tribal citizens residing on the reservations of ITCAs other Member Tribes in Arizona.  
39.  In recognition of the particular burdens Native voters would otherwise face, under 
3 
a stipulation in Gonzalez v. Arizona, members of federally recognized Indian tribes are entitled to 
4 
present Tribal identification at the polls that does not include a numbered street address. See 
5 
Gonzalez v. Arizona, CV 06-1268-PHX-ROS, Joint Stipulation, (D. Ariz. Apr. 18, 2008). Voters 
6 
needing this accommodation are given a provisional ballot that is counted without additional 
7 
documentation. 
8 
40.  The new DPOR Requirement for voter registration under HB 2492 contains no 
9 
accommodation for tribal identification that does not include a residential address or otherwise 
10 
does not meet the requirements of Arizona Statute  16-579. 
11 
41.  As a result, members of tribes who are eligible to vote and have identification 
12  sufficient to enable them to cast a ballot in person under the Gonzalez stipulation will nonetheless 
13  be prohibited from registering to vote under HB 2492. 
14  42.  The DPOR Requirement also makes no provision for how people experiencing 
homelessness can comply with its mandates and register to vote.  
15 
43.  The  DPOR  Requirement  will  also  burden  voters  who  would  otherwise  take 
16 
advantage of voter registration drives.  
17 
44.  Additional documentation requirements for registration beyond a standardized 
18 
form make traditional voter registration activity nearly impossible. Potential voters often do not 
19 
carry  documentary  proof  of  residence  with  them  while  out  in  the  community.  And  those 
20 
conducting voter registration drives cannot easily incorporate the equipment needed to copy such 
21 
documentation for submission with paper voter registration forms.  
22 
  9 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 10 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  45.  Arizona voters may register to vote using either the Arizona Voter Registration 
2  Form (State Form) or the National Mail Voter Registration Form (Federal Form), which is 
promulgated by the U.S. Election Assistance Commission (EAC) under the NVRA.  
3 
46.  Arizona voters may also register online (if they have a valid Arizona Drivers 
4 
License and/or an Arizona non-operating I.D. card issued by the Motor Vehicle Division), in 
5 
person at a County Recorders office, or at a NVRA-mandated public agency.  
6 
47.  Under the NVRA, all states must accept and use the Federal Form, which only 
7 
requires attestation of residence and does not require documentary proof of residence. 52 U.S.C.  
8 
 20505. 
9 
48.  The NVRA preempts any attempt by states to impose additional requirements to 
10 
prove citizenship, residence, or any other qualification above and beyond those provided by the 
11 
Federal Form. 
12  49.  HB 2492s DPOR Requirement purports to prohibit county election officials from 
13  registering otherwise eligible votersincluding those who submitted a completed Federal Form
14  unless they provide DPOR, in flagrant violation of federal law.  
50.  The Supreme Court rejected Arizonas attempt to impose a documentary proof of 
15 
citizenship requirement on registrants using the Federal Form less than a decade ago. See Arizona 
16 
v. Inter Tribal Council of Arizona, 570 U.S. 1, 18 (2013) (holding that the NVRAs requirement 
17 
that states accept and use the Federal Form acts as both a ceiling and a floor for registering to 
18 
vote in federal elections).  
19 
51.  The NVRA also requires that certain mandated public assistance agencies provide 
20 
voter registration services using the Federal Form or its equivalent. 52 U.S.C.  20506. 
21 
22 
  10 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 11 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  52.  To the extent HB 2492 seeks to impose the DPOR Requirement on applicants 
2  registering at NVRA-mandated agencies, it is preempted by the NVRA because an equivalent 
form would not require documentary proof of residence.  
3 
53.  Under the NVRA, a voter registration application provided at a states motor 
4 
vehicle authority may require only the minimum amount of information necessary to (i) prevent 
5 
duplicate voter registrations; and (ii) enable State election officials to assess the eligibility of the 
6 
applicant and to administer voter registration and other parts of the election process. 52 U.S.C.  
7 
20504.  
8 
54.  The Arizona Motor Vehicle Division implements these provisions, and the DPOR 
9 
Requirement is preempted by the NVRA to the extent it is inconsistent with the Motor Vehicle 
10 
Divisions federal voter registration obligations.  
11 
Birthplace Requirement 
12  55.  HB 2492 mandates that eligible Arizonans provide their birthplace when registering 
13  to vote and directs county election officials not to register voters who fail to list their place of birth 
14  on the grounds that such an application is incomplete. HB 2492  4 (to be codified at A.R.S.  
16-121.01).  
15 
56.  A voters birthplace is wholly immaterial to their qualifications to vote. Arizonas 
16

7

164.  Official barriers to Native Americans ability to register to vote persisted in Arizona 
3 
until 1948. See Harrison v. Laveen, 196 P.2d 456 (Ariz. 1984). Once Native Americans became 
4 
United States citizens pursuant to the Indian Citizenship Act of 1924, a number of localities in 
5 
Arizona continued to reject Native Americans voter registration applications.21 Some advanced 
6 
the theory that living on a reservation made enrolled members non-residents of the state.22 Others 
7 
alleged that Supreme Court caselaw supposedly made Native Americans wards of the United 
8 
States and therefore ineligible to vote under the Arizona constitutional provision barring persons 
9 
under guardianship from casting a ballot.23 
10 
165.  The policy of rejecting Native American voter registrants living on reservations 
11 
became official statewide in 1928 when the Arizona Supreme Court adopted the guardianship 
12  theory. The policy was extended in practice and later officially by the Attorney General to all 
13  Native Americans, including those living outside of Reservations.24 Native Americans only won 
14  the right to vote in Arizona after a lawsuit filed by Native veterans who returned home after serving 
the United States in World War II and had their voter registrations denied.25

other Ndee who were subsequently relocated to the Reservation, make up the Tribe.

16

June 7, 1897, 30 Stat. 64 (creating the Fort Apache Reservation and establishing the Fort Apache

11 
(4)   Enter a declaratory judgment pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  2201 and 2202 declaring 
12  that the challenged HB 2492 and HB 2243 provisions are preempted by the National 
13  Voter Registration Act, 52 U.S.C.  20501, et seq. 
14  (5)  Enter declaratory judgment pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  2201 and 2202 declaring that 
the challenged HB 2492 and HB 2243 provisions violate Section 2 of the Voting 
15 
Rights Act of 1965. 
16 
(4)  Grant Plaintiffs preliminary and/or permanent injunctive relief by: 
17 
  a.   Ordering that Defendant and Intervenor-Defendants are prohibited 
18 
from enforcing the challenged HB 2492 and HB 2243 provisions with 
19 
respect to any election;  
20 
  b.  Ordering that Defendant and Intervenor-Defendants are prohibited 
21 
from rejecting, causing to be rejected, cancelling, and/or causing to be 
22 
  70 
23 
 
24 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 67   Filed 07/18/22   Page 71 of 72
 
 
   
 
1  cancelled any voter registration or voter registration application on the 
2  grounds of the challenged HB 2492 and 2243 provisions; 
  c.  Ordering that Defendant and Intervenor Defendants are prohibited 
3 
from transmitting or using any voter registration list for the purpose and/or 
4 
effect of investigating and/or prosecuting voters on the grounds of the 
5 
challenged HB 2492 and HB 2243 provisions; 
6 
(5)  Retain jurisdiction over Defendant and Intervenor-Defendants for such period of 
7 
time as may be appropriate to ensure Defendants and Intervenor-Defendants 
8 
compliance with relief ordered by this Court; 
9 
(6)  Award Plaintiffs reasonable attorneys fees and costs pursuant to 42 U.S.C.  1988, 
10 
52 U.S.C.  10310(e), and 52 U.S.C.  20510(c); and 
11 
(7)  Grant Plaintiffs such other and further relief as may be just and equitable.

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 3 of 68
  Plaintiffs Poder Latinx, Chicanos Por La Causa, Inc. and Chicanos Por La Causa 
1 
2  Action Fund (together, CPLC) (collectively, Plaintiffs) seek declaratory and injunctive 
3 
relief as follows: 
4 
NATURE OF ACTION 
5 
1.  This suit challenges provisions recently enacted as part of Arizona House Bill 
6 
7  2492 (HB 2492) and Arizona House Bill 2243 (HB 2243) that overhaul Arizonas 
8 
already  highly  restrictive  and  needlessly  complex  voter  registration  system.  Once 
9 
implemented  in  2023,  the  statutes  new  citizenship  investigation  procedures  for  both 
10 
registration applicants and existing registered voters, removal mechanisms, and proof of 
11 
residence requirement will operate in tandem to target Arizonas naturalized citizen voters, 
12 
13  who are predominantly racial and ethnic minority voters,1 and in particular, the Latinx 
14 
communities that Plaintiffs serve. These provisionsmany of which are found nowhere else 
15 
in the countryviolate the U.S. Constitutions prohibitions on discriminatory and arbitrary 
16 
treatment of voters and its guarantees of equal protection and due process, the National Voter 
17 
18  Registration Act (NVRA), and the Civil Rights Act of 1964. 
19 
2.  When HB 2492 and HB 2243 take effect next year,2 these new mandates will 
20 
immediately result in the inaccurate, arbitrary, discriminatory, and ultimately unlawful 
21 
22                                                
1 United States Census Bureau, Table S0501, Selected Characteristics of the Native and 
23 
Foreign-Born  Populations,  available  at 
24  https://data.census.gov/cedsci/table?q=S0501%3A%20SELECTED%20CHARACTERIST
ICS%20OF%20THE%20NATIVE%20AND%20FOREIGN-
25 
BORN%20POPULATIONS&g=0400000US04&tid=ACSST5Y2020.S0501.  
26  2 A separate bill, Senate Bill 1638 (SB 1638), delays the effective date of HB 2492 until 
January 1, 2023. See SB 1638, Section 4(A).  On information and belief, the Arizona 
27 
Secretary of State takes the position that HB 2243s implementation is also effectively 
28  delayed until January 1, 2023 because HB 2243 alters a statutory provision newly created 
1 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 4 of 68
treatment of naturalized voters throughout Arizonaall of whom are United States citizens 
1 
2  who may be erroneously flagged as non-citizens based on old and inaccurate data or the 
3 
personal beliefs  of  local  officials,  subjected  to unwarranted  extra  scrutiny,  unlawfully 
4 
removed from the rolls, and even prosecuted. HB 2492 and HB 2243s pernicious effects 
5 
will be felt disproportionately by Arizonas racial and ethnic minority voters, including 
6 
7  Latinx  voters.  Consequently,  the  challenged  laws  will  do  severe  harm  to  the  voter 
8 
registration operations and civic engagement mission of community organizations like 
9 
Plaintiffs, which are engaged in securing the trust of Latinx voters and assisting them in 
10 
registering to vote. The challenged laws will also directly harm the communities and 
11 
12  constituencies served by Plaintiffs.  
13 
3.  To prevent the harm to the community of voters Plaintiffs Poder Latinx and 
14 
CPLC serve and the undermining of its voter registration and civic engagement operations, 
15 
Plaintiffs seek to enjoin the enforcement of HB 2492 and HB 2243s vague, arbitrary, and 
16 
17  unconstitutional procedures for investigating the U.S. citizenship of registration applicants 
18 
who apply with the NVRA mail-in registration form (the Federal Registration Form or 
19 
Federal  Form)  and  currently  registered  voters,  and  acting  on  the  results  of  those 
20 
investigations. The specific challenged provisions within HB 2492 and HB 2243 include the 
21 
22  following:  
23 
 
24 
 
25 
                                              
26 
by HB 2492. On information and belief, the county recorders are not in a position to 
27  implement the changes made by HB 2492 and HB 2243 without the Arizona Secretary of 
States office. 
28 
2 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 5 of 68
 The Citizenship Investigation Provisions: 
1 
2    Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-121.01(D), 16-121.01(E), and 16-121.01(F), as enacted 
3 
by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  4;  
4 
  Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-143, as enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  7;  
5 
  Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(A)(10), as enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99 
6 
7   8, as further amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 370  2; and  
8 
  Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(F), 16-165(G), 16-165(H), 16-165(I), 16-165(J), as 
9 
enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 370  2. 
10 
The Documentary Proof of Residence (DPOR) Requirement 
11 
12    Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-123, as enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  5. 
13 
  Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-121.01(A), as amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99 
14 
 4. 
15 
16  4.  The  Citizenship  Investigation  Provisions  and  the  DPOR  requirement  are 
17 
referred to herein collectively as the Challenged Provisions. 
18 
5.  HB 2492 and HB 2243 require Defendant Secretary of State Katie Hobbs 
19 
(Defendant Hobbs), Defendant Attorney General Mark Brnovich (Defendant Brnovich), 
20 
Defendant Maricopa County Recorder Stephen Richer, Defendant Pima County Recorder 
21 
22  Gabriella Czares-Kelly, Defendant Yuma County Recorder Richard Colwell (collectively, 
23 
Defendants), and the county recorders in Arizonas other counties to implement the 
24 
Citizenship Investigation Provisions. These provisions require Arizona election and law 
25 
enforcement officials, including each of the Defendants, to compare voter registration data 
26 
27  to all available federal, state, and local databases in search of information that registration 
28 
3 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 6 of 68
applicants and registered voters lack U.S. citizenship. HB 2492 and 2243 authorize county 
1 
2  recorders and Defendant Brnovich to use information that the applicant or registered voter 
3 
is not a United States citizen to reject registration forms, cancel existing registered voters 
4 
records, and subject these erroneously flagged individuals to investigation and prosecution. 
5 
These statutes require the rejection or cancellation of a voters registration based on any 
6 
7  citizenship information the county recorder obtains and confirms, regardless of whether 
8 
that  information  is  current,  accurate,  and  validated,  and  even  if  that  information  is 
9 
superseded by the individuals subsequent naturalization.  
10 
6.  Governor Doug Ducey himself identified serious legal problems with this new 
11 
12  process. When the legislature passed House Bill 2617 (HB 2617) earlier this past session, 
13  a bill that contained many of the same provisions later included in HB 2243, he vetoed it.3 
14 
Governor Ducey issued a veto statement that argued the following: 
15 
It is equally important that our laws include safeguards to protect the vote of 
16  any Arizonan who is eligible and lawfully registered. . . . 
 
17  H.B. 2617 requires a county recorder to cancel the voter registration of a voter 
if the recorder receives information that provides the basis for determining that 
18  the person is not a qualified elector. The implementation of this provision is 
vague and lacks any guidance for how a county recorder would confirm such 
19  a determination. Our lawfully registered voters deserve to know that their right 
to vote will not be disturbed without sufficient due process. This provision 
20  leaves our election system vulnerable to bad actors who could seek to falsely 
allege a voter is not a qualified elector. 
21   
. . . . The subjectivity of this provision, as well as a lack of guardrails against 
22  false claims, included in H.B. 2617 leaves voter registration susceptible to 
being canceled based on fiction rather than fact.  
23   
24 
25 
                                              
26 
3 A revised version of HB 2617 was added into HB 2243 late in Arizonas 2022 legislative 
27  session. Governor Ducey signed HB 2243 into law on July 6, 2022. As described infra, some 
provisions from HB 2617 were amended in HB 2243, but others remained unchanged. 
28 
4 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 7 of 68
See Letter from Governor Ducey to Rusty Bowers, Speaker of the Arizona State House of 
1 
2  Representatives,  (May  27,  2022),  available 
3 
at https://www.azleg.gov/govlettr/55leg/2r/hb2617.pdf. Just as the phrase information that 
4 
the person . . . is not a United States citizen was, in Governor Duceys words, vague and 
5 
left the system vulnerable to bad actors, HB 2492s use of the same disqualification 
6 
7  standard suffers from the same fatal defects. Similarly, HB 2243s further amendments to 
8 
Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165 ultimately perpetuate many of the same legal problems that caused 
9 
the Governor to veto this legislation the first time around, including but not limited to the 
10 
laws vulnerability to third-party false accusations. 
11 
12  7.  A clear example of this problem is newly created Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(H), 
13 
which runs afoul of clear precedents under the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments, which 
14 
ban racial and/or national origin discrimination in voting. This provision authorizes county 
15 
recorders to act on mere suspicions and any other subjective reason to believe [that 
16 
17  registered voters] are not United States citizens: 
18  To the extent practicable, each month the county recorder shall compare 
persons who are registered to vote in that county and who the county recorder 
19  has reason to believe are not United States citizens and persons who are 
registered to vote without satisfactory evidence of citizenship as prescribed by 
20  Section  16-166  with  the  Systematic  Alien  Verification  for  Entitlements 
program  maintained  by  the  United  States  Citizenship  and  Immigration 
21  Services to verify the citizenship status of the persons registered. 
 
22 
Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(H), as enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 370  2 (emphasis 
23 
added). This provision is an open invitation for discriminatory, unequal, and arbitrary 
24 
treatment of registered voters, particularly naturalized racial and ethnic minority voters. As 
25 
26  with similarly vague, undefined provisions in HB 2492 (and vetoed HB 2617), any kind of 
27 
informationincluding a false third-party accusation or information county recorders 
28 
5 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 8 of 68
learn by interacting with or observing the registered voter including their perceived race or 
1 
2  ethnicitycan give a county recorder reason to believe that a registered voter is not a 
3 
United States citizen. Receipt of such information triggers Defendants obligation to 
4 
subject those voters to extra investigation and potential removal from the statewide voter 
5 
registration database. Under this provision, a county recorder is licensed to act on mere 
6 
7  suspicion or rumor, or a prejudiced view of the registered voters race, ethnicity, national 
8 
origin, English proficiency, or dress. Far from eliminating the threat of third-party false 
9 
accusations Governor Ducey identified, HB 2243 merely shifted it to another vague, open-
10 
ended provision. 
11 
12  8.  Even prior to the enactment of HB 2492 and HB 2243, Arizonas documentary 
13 
proof of citizenship (DPOC) requirement, first adopted in 2004 as part of Proposition 200, 
14 
was the only such law enforced in the nation. Now the Challenged Provisions will impose 
15 
additional  restrictions  on  Arizonas  already  uniquely  burdensome  and  byzantine  voter 
16 
17  registration system. No other state in the country is enforcing such draconian measures. The 
18 
experience of the other 49 states that are not imposing these unique burdens on citizens 
19 
attempting to vote demonstrates that the restrictions imposed by HB 2492 and HB 2243 are 
20 
unnecessary to assess voter registration applicants or registered voters qualifications. 
21 
22  9.  The Citizenship Investigation Provisions in HB 2492 and HB 2243 violate the 
23 
U.S. Constitution and federal law in several ways.  
24 
  First, the Challenged Provisions contained in HB 2492 violate Section 8(b) of the 
25 
National Voter Registration Act, which requires uniform and non-discriminatory 
26 
voter registration processes. Naturalized citizens are treated in a non-uniform 
27 
28 
6 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 9 of 68
manner under HB 2492, and Arizona voters will face discriminatory treatment 
1 
2  based on their race, ethnicity, and national origin.4  
3 
  Second, HB 2243s creation of 16-165(H) violates Title I of the 1964 Civil Rights 
4 
Act, specifically 52 U.S.C.  10101(a)(2)(A), because it subjects different groups 
5 
of  eligible  voters  to  different  standard[s],  practice[s],  or  procedure[s]  for 
6 
7  verifying voting eligibility, based on nothing more than a county recorders 
8 
perception that there is reason to believe [that registered voters] are  not United 
9 
States citizens. Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(H). 
10 
  Third, Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(H) will result in the discriminatory and arbitrary 
11 
12  treatment  of  naturalized  voters  and,  by  extension,  Latinx  voters.  This  new 
13 
provision  vests  county  recorders  with  the  explicit  authority  to  act  on  mere 
14 
suspicions of non-citizenship, and to subject voters to discriminatory and unequal 
15 
treatment based on any perception that the county recorders staff deems to be 
16 
17  indicative  of  non-citizenship.  It  violates  the  Fourteenth  and  Fifteenth 
18 
Amendments prohibitions on the discriminatory treatment of voters on the basis 
19 
of race and/or national origin. 
20 
  Fourth, the Citizenship Investigation Provisions are bereft of any rules or criteria 
21 
22  for Defendants to apply in deciding who is and who is not a U.S. citizen. Whereas 
23 
the preexisting DPOC requirement contains an objective list of the specific forms 
24 
25                                                
4 Plaintiffs have submitted a second NVRA notice letter to Defendant Secretary of State 
26 
Hobbs, identifying NVRA violations in HB 2243, which was enacted at the end of this 
27  legislative session. Based on an effective date of January for HB 2243, these NVRA claims 
cannot be added to this complaint until late October. 
28 
7 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 10 of 68
of documentation that prove a registration applicants U.S. citizenship, Ariz. Rev. 
1 
2  Stat.  16-166(F), HB 2492 and HB 2243 do not articulate what information 
3 
will prove that a registration applicant or registered voter is not a United States 
4 
citizen. In particular, HB 2492 and HB 2243 fail to inform Arizona state and 
5 
local officials as to how they should review and evaluate outdated citizenship 
6 
7  status  information  contained  in  government  databases.  Without  specific 
8 
instructions, the statutes invite Defendants to make inconsistent and irreconcilable 
9 
determinations as to applicants and voters current citizenship status. Different 
10 
county recorders and different staff members within a county recorders office 
11 
12  will necessarily apply varying rules, standards, and methods in comparing voter 
13 
registration  applicants  and  registered  voters  to  the  government  and  voter 
14 
registration databases that they are required to search pursuant to HB 2492 and 
15 
HB  2243.  Ariz.  Rev.  Stat.    16-165(H)  especially  gives  county  recorders 
16 
17  unlimited discretion to subject registered voters they suspect are not U.S. citizens 
18 
to extra, unwarranted investigation, and to deny them their right to vote. Such 
19 
arbitrary and disparate treatment of voter registration applicants and currently 
20 
registered  voters  violates  the  Equal  Protection  Clause  of  the  Fourteenth 
21 
22  Amendment. 
23    Fifth, the failure to provide naturalized-citizen registration applicants or existing 
24 
voters who are erroneously flagged as non-citizens with an opportunity to contest 
25 
these  citizenship  status  determinations  violates  the  Fourteenth  Amendments 
26 
protections for procedural due process. While registration applicants who do not 
27 
28 
8 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 11 of 68
include DPOC with the federal form must be notified when county recorders 
1 
2  locate information that the applicant is not a United States citizen, Ariz. Rev. 
3 
Stat.  16-121.01(E), as amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  4, HB 2492 
4 
does not afford these applicants an opportunity to be heard and attest to or even 
5 
provide documentary proof of their U.S. citizenship before their voter registration 
6 
7  application is rejected. Combined with the arbitrariness of these open-ended and 
8 
vague investigation directives, HB 2492 violates the Due Process Clause. 
9 
10.  Finally, Plaintiffs also challenge HB 2492s documentary proof of residence 
10 
(DPOR)  requirement  as  a  violation  of  the  National  Voter  Registration  Act,  which 
11 
12  preempts contrary state laws under the U.S. Supreme Courts decision in Arizona v. Inter 
13 
Tribal Council of Arizona. (ITCA), 570 U.S. 1 (2013). 
14 
11.  Plaintiffs challenge these provisions of HB 2492 and HB 2243 under the 
15 
Fourteenth Amendments Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses, as enforced by 42 
16 
17  U.S.C.  1983, the National Voter Registration Act, 52 U.S.C.  20505, 20507, and the 
18 
1964 Civil Rights Act, 52 U.S.C.  10101(a)(2)(A). Poder Latinx and CPLC respectfully 
19 
seek a declaratory judgment and preliminary and permanent injunctive relief. 
20 
JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
21   
12.  This Court has federal subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  1331 
22 
23  over this suit because it arises under the Constitution and laws of the United States. 
24 
13.  This Court has jurisdiction to grant declaratory relief pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  
25 
2201 and 2202. 
26 
27 
28 
9 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 12 of 68
14.  Plaintiffs claims under the NVRA are proper because Arizona is covered by 
1 
2  the NVRA. 52 U.S.C.  20502(4). 
3 
15.  This Court has jurisdiction to award attorneys fees and costs pursuant to 42 
4 
U.S.C.  1988 and 28 U.S.C.  1920. 
5 
16.  This  Court  has  personal  jurisdiction  over  Defendant  Hobbs,  Defendant 
6 
7  Brnovich, Defendant Richer, Defendant Czares-Kelly, and Defendant Colwell, who are 
8 
sued in their official capacities. Defendants Hobbs and Brnovich are state officials, and 
9 
Defendant Richer is a county official, each of whom reside in Arizona and work in Phoenix, 
10 
Arizona. Defendants Czares-Kelly and Colwell are county officials, each of whom reside 
11 
12  in Arizona. 
13 
17.  Venue is appropriate in the District of Arizona because a substantial part of 
14 
the events giving rise to these claims occurred and continues to occur in this district, making 
15 
venue also proper under 28 U.S.C.  1391(b)(2). 
16 
17  PARTIES 
18 
18.  Plaintiff Poder Latinx is a non-partisan civic and social justice organization 
19 
with a vision to build political power for the Latinx community to become decision-makers 
20 
in this democracy and advocate on economic, immigrant, and environmental issues. Its 
21 
22  mission is to build a sustained bloc of Latinx voters in battleground states. It operates in 
23  Arizona, Florida, and Georgia.5 Poder Latinx works locally to expand the electorate by 
24 
conducting year-round civic engagement activities, community empowerment, leadership

27.  Since 2005, Arizona election law has contained a documentary proof of

citizenship (DPOC) requirement for voter registration applicants. When a person registers

to vote, they must provide one of the following forms of evidence of citizenship from the

7  statutory list:

identification license that the person has provided satisfactory proof of United

States citizenship.

citizenship to the satisfaction of the county recorder.

15  passport identifying the applicant and the applicants passport number or

naturalization documents or the number of the certificate of naturalization. If

shall not be included in the registration rolls until the number of the certificate

of  naturalization  is  verified  with  the  United  States  immigration  and

number or tribal enrollment number.
