7  Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Fifteenth Amendment, and 42 U.S.C.  1983.  
8 
COUNT FOUR 
(All Plaintiffs) 
9 
(Arbitrary and Disparate Treatment of Voter Registration Applicants Using the 
Federal Form and Currently Registered Voters, Equal Protection Clause of 
10 
Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C.  1983) 
The Citizenship Investigation Provisions (Both HB 2492 and HB 2243) 
11 
 
12  120.  The factual allegations contained in paragraphs 1 through 119 are incorporated 
13 
into Count Four, as though fully set forth herein. 
14 
121.  The U.S. Supreme Court has long forbidden arbitrary allocation of the right to 
15 
vote and arbitrary registration practices. Supreme Court precedent prohibits arbitrary and 
16 
17  disparate treatment in either the allocation of the franchise or the manner of its exercise. 
18 
Bush v. Gore, 531 U.S. 98, 104 (2000); id. at 10409 (concluding that absence of specific 
19 
standards to implement vague intent of the voter standard caused arbitrary and disparate 
20 
treatment in manual recount in violation of the Equal Protection Clause); see also Hunter 
21 
22  v. Hamilton Cnty. Bd. of Elections, 635 F.3d 219, 235, 23942 (6th Cir. 2011) (applying 
23 
Bush v. Gore to conclude lack of specific standards for reviewing provisional ballots had 
24 
resulted in unconstitutionally arbitrary and uneven exercise of discretion). 
25 
122.  Arbitrarily allocating the right to vote has long been held unconstitutional.  See 
26 
27  Louisiana v. United States, 380 U.S. at 15053 (The cherished right of people in a country 
28 
53 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 56 of 68
like ours to vote cannot be obliterated by the use of laws like this, which leave the voting 
1 
2  fate of a citizen to the passing whim or impulse of an individual registrar.). Indeed, any 
3 
arbitrary impairment of the right to vote violates equal protection. Baker v. Carr, 369 U.S. 
4 
186, 208 (1962) (A citizens right to a vote free of arbitrary impairment by state action has 
5 
been judicially recognized as a right secured by the Constitution . . .). 
6 
7  123.  Arizonas previously enacted DPOC law enumerates the specific forms of 
8 
proof that a voter registration applicant can provide to establish U.S. citizenship. Ariz. Rev. 
9 
Stat.  16-166(F). HB 2492, by contrast, does not enumerate what specific information 
10 
proves that a voter registration applicant using the federal form or a registered voter is not 
11 
12  a U.S. citizen. See Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-121.01(D) & (E).  The latter contains only a vague 
13 
instruction that leaves the registration applicant or registered voters citizenship status to the 
14 
discretion  and  subjective,  arbitrary  determinations  of  Defendant  Hobbs,  Defendant 
15 
Brnovich, and county recorder offices staff. 
16 
17  124.  On the front end of the voter registration process, county recorders who 
18 
receive a federal registration form that is not accompanied by DPOC must attempt to verify 
19 
the  citizenship  status  of  the  applicant  and  must  compare  the  registration  applicants 
20 
information to every federal, state, and local government database and every other database 
21 
22  relating to voter registration to which the county recorder has access. 
23 
125.  HB 2492 specifies that  
24 
[i]f the county recorder or other officer in charge of elections matches the 
25  [federal form] applicant with information that the applicant is not a United 
States citizen, the county recorder or other officer in charge of elections shall 
26 
reject the application, notify the applicant that the application was rejected 
because the applicant is not a United States citizen and forward the application 
27 
28 
54 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 57 of 68
to  the  county  attorney  and  Attorney  General  for  investigation.  
1 
 
2  Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-121.01(E), as enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  4. What 
3 
constitutes information that the applicant is not a United States citizen is left unspecified 
4 
and for the discretion and subjective, arbitrary determinations of Arizonas 15 county 
5 
recorders offices and their staff members. How county recorders and their staff must 
6 
7  evaluate and interpret stale information that a person lacked U.S. citizenship at some time 
8 
in the past, during for instance a government transaction for driver licensing or public 
9 
assistance, is also left unspecified. The flagged individuals likely naturalization as a U.S. 
10 
citizen subsequent to that outdated government transaction record but prior to registering as 
11 
12  an Arizona voter is left unaddressed. The legal void created by these vague instructions will 
13 
be filled with the judgment calls and discretion of county recorders and their staff who will 
14 
inevitably  make  inconsistent  and  irreconcilable  determinations  on  voter  registration 
15 
applicants  citizenship  status.  Such  arbitrary  and  disparate  treatment  concerning  the 
16 
17  allocation of the right to vote is HB 2492s inevitable consequence. 
18 
126.  A similar process is required on the back end of the voter registration process. 
19 
For  registered  Arizona  voters  who  have  not  provided  DPOC  and  can  only  vote  in 
20 
congressional elections, HB 2492 requires Defendant Brnovich to engage in the same wide-
21 
22  ranging  database  review  to  identify  voters  who  are  purportedly  not  U.S.  citizens  and 
23 
prosecute individuals who are found to not be United States citizens. Ariz. Rev. Stat.  
24 
16-143, as amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  7. 
25 
127.  HB 2243 requires the removal of voters from the statewide voter registration 
26 
database [w]hen the county recorder obtains information pursuant to this section and 
27 
28 
55 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 58 of 68
confirms that the person registered is not a United States citizen. Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-
1 
2  165(A)(10), as enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws ch. 370,  2. Once again, HB 2243 does 
3 
not specify what type, set, or combination of information establishes that a registered voter 
4 
is not a United States citizen currently; nor do these provisions acknowledge, let alone 
5 
address, these flagged registered voters likely naturalization subsequent to the government 
6 
7  records creation but before their registration as a voter.  Nor does the statute specify what 
8 
it means to confirm a person is not a U.S. citizen. These vague instructions will inevitably 
9 
lead to arbitrary and disparate treatment of registered voters and arbitrary allocation of the 
10 
right to vote. HB 2243 therefore authorizes county recorders and their staff to rely on 
11 
12  outdated government data or unverified, unsubstantiated statements regarding a registered 
13 
voters citizenship status to remove that voter from the rolls. Even if not all county recorders, 
14 
and not all staff members rely on such unreliable information, the result will be the arbitrary 
15 
and disparate treatment of naturalized registered Arizona voters. 
16 
17  128.  There is no database that has current, up-to-date citizenship status information 
18 
for all residents of the United States or Arizona. All databases that contain citizenship status 
19 
information are based on transactions or events that took place at some point in the past. 
20 
Relying on stale, old government data as if it were evidence of a registration applicants or 
21 
22  registered voters present-day citizenship status is illogical and irrational and will inevitably 
23 
lead to arbitrary and disparate treatment and arbitrary allocation of the right to vote. 
24 
129.  Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(H) especially gives county recorders unlimited 
25 
discretion  to  subject  registered  voters  to  subject  registered  U.S.  citizens  to  extra, 
26 
unwarranted investigation and potentially registration cancellation when they merely have 
27 
28 
56 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 59 of 68
reason to believe [certain voters] are not United States citizens. This will inevitably lead 
1 
2  to arbitrary and inconsistent treatment of voters statewide and within counties. 
3 
130.  HB 2492 and HB 2243s Citizenship Investigation Provisions, including the 
4 
registration cancellation provision, subject naturalized voter registration applicants and 
5 
naturalized  registered  voters  to  arbitrary  and  disparate  treatment  within  counties  and 
6 
7  statewide, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.  
8 
131.  At all relevant times, Defendants have acted under color of state law. 
9 
132.  Defendants have violated and will continue to violate the Equal Protection 
10 
Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C.  1983.  
11 
COUNT FIVE 
12 
(All Plaintiffs) 
(Violation of Procedural Due Process as to Voter Registration Applicants Using the 
13 
Federal Voter Registration Form Who Do Not Provide Documentary Proof of 
Citizenship, Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C.  1983) 
14 
HB 2492 Section 5 (Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-121.01(E)) 
 
15 
133.  The factual allegations contained in paragraphs 1 through 132 are incorporated 
16 
into Count Five, as though fully set forth herein. 
17 
18  134.  The  Due  Process  Clause  of  the  Fourteenth  Amendment  prohibits  the 
19 
deprivation of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law. U.S. Const. amend. 
20 
XIV. The Due Process Clause forbids the governmental deprivation of substantive rights 
21 
without constitutionally adequate procedure. Armstrong v. Reynolds, 22 F.4th 1058, 1066 
22 
23  (9th Cir. 2022) (quoting Shanks v. Dressel, 540 F.3d 1082, 109091 (9th Cir. 2008)). The 
24 
touchstone of procedural due process is notice and an opportunity to be heard. Miranda v. 
25 
City of Casa Grande, 15 F.4th 1219, 1225 (9th Cir. 2021). 
26 
27 
28 
57 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 60 of 68
135.  Courts assessing procedural due process claims must weigh (1) the private 
1 
2  interest affected; (2) the risk of erroneous deprivation through the procedures used, and the 
3 
value of additional procedural safeguards; and (3) the governments interest, including the 
4 
burdens of additional procedural requirements. Shinault v. Hawks, 782 F.3d 1053, 1057 
5 
(9th Cir. 2015) (citing Mathews v. Eldridge, 424 U.S. 319, 335 (1976)). 
6 
7  136.  A protected property interest is present where an individual has a reasonable 
8 
expectation of entitlement deriving from existing rules or understandings that stem from an 
9 
independent source such as state law. Power Rd.-Williams Field, LLC v. Gilbert, 14 F. 
10 
Supp. 3d 1304, 1311 (D. Ariz. 2014) (quoting Wedges/Ledges of Cal., Inc. v. City of 
11 
12  Phoenix, 24 F.3d 56, 62 (9th Cir. 1994)). The Ninth Circuit has long held that applicants 
13 
have a property interest protectible under the Due Process Clause where the regulations 
14 
establishing entitlement to the benefit are . . . mandatory in nature. Foss v. NMFS, 161 F.3d 
15 
584, 588 (9th Cir. 1998); Ching v. Mayorkas, 725 F.3d 1149, 1155 (9th Cir. 2013) ([A] 
16 
17  benefit is not a protected entitlement if government officials may grant or deny it in their 
18 
discretion. (quotation omitted)). The same is true with respect to the creation of a liberty 
19 
interest.  See  Mendoza  v.  Blodgett,  960  F.2d  1425,  142829  (9th  Cir.  1992)  (A 
20 
state creates a protected liberty interest when it places substantive limitations on official 
21 
22  discretion.  .  .  .  The  regulations  also  must  contain  explicitly  mandatory 
23 
language, i.e., specific directives to the decisionmaker that if the regulations substantive 
24 
predicates are present, a particular outcome must follow, in order to create a liberty interest. 
25 
(quoting Kentucky. Dept of Corr. v. Thompson, 490 U.S. 454, 463 (1989))). 
26 
27 
28 
58 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 61 of 68
137.  Under the U.S. Constitution, the right to vote is precious and fundamental. 
1 
2  Harper v. Virginia State Bd. of Elections, 383 U.S. 663, 670 (1966).  The right to vote is of 
3 
the most fundamental significance under our constitutional structure.  Burdick v. Takushi, 
4 
504 U.S. 428, 433 (1992) (quoting Illinois Bd. of Elections v. Socialist Workers Party, 440 
5 
U.S. 173, 184 (1979)).  The right to vote freely for the candidate of ones choice is of the 
6 
7  essence of a democratic society, and any restrictions on that right strike at the heart of a 
8 
representative government.  Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 555 (1964).  Accordingly, 
9 
procedural due process protections apply to the right to vote as a constitutionally protected 
10 
liberty interest.  
11 
12  138.  Arizona law creates a protectible interest in voter registration by guaranteeing 
13 
the right to register to every U.S. citizen who is at least 18 years old, who has been a resident 
14 
of the state for at least 29 days before Election Day, who has not been convicted of a 
15 
disqualifying felony, and who timely registers to vote in accordance with the rules and 
16 
17  procedures established under state law and regulations. Ariz. Const.  2(A); see Ariz. Rev. 
18 
Stat.  16-101, 16-121. It does not give the county recorders discretion to deny the 
19 
applications of individuals who satisfy these criteria, rules, and procedures. See Ariz. Rev. 
20 
Stat.  16-163(A) (The county recorder, on receipt of a registration in proper form, shall 
21 
22  assign the registration record to its proper precinct and alphabetical arrangement in the 
23 
general county register. (emphasis added)). 
24 
139.  HB 2492 amended Arizonas voter qualification statutes such that a registrant 
25 
must provide[ ] satisfactory evidence of citizenship to qualify to register. Ariz. Rev. Stat. 
26 
 16-101(A)(1), 16-121(A), as amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws ch. 99,  1, 3. However, 
27 
28 
59 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 62 of 68
even if a federal form applicant does not submit DPOC, the requirement is fully satisfied if 
1 
2  county recorders staff can independently verify a federal form applicants U.S. citizenship. 
3 
Id.  16-121.01(D), as amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99,  4. 
4 
140.  When a governing statute is sufficiently mandatory to grant an applicant a 
5 
vested interest in an entitlement or benefit, applicants who claim to meet the eligibility 
6 
7  requirements have a right to due process in the evaluation of their applications, including 
8 
in the methods used to assess their eligibility. Griffeth v. Detrich, 603 F.2d 118, 121 (9th 
9 
Cir. 1979); Holohan v. Massanari, 246 F.3d 1195, 1209 (9th Cir. 2001) (recognizing that 
10 
applicants  for  social  security  disability  benefits  are  entitled  to  due  process  in  the 
11 
12  determination of their claims because they have property interest in benefits); Stivers v. 
13 
Pierce, 71 F.3d 732, 74041 (9th Cir. 1995) (It is well-settled that the Due Process Clause 
14 
prevents the state from depriving a plaintiff of a protected property interest without a fair 
15 
trial in a fair tribunal. . . . This requirement applies not only to courts, but also to state 
16 
17  administrative agencies charged with applying eligibility criteria for licenses. (internal 
18 
citation omitted)); see also Ressler v. Pierce, 692 F.2d 1212, 1216 (9th Cir. 1982) (holding 
19 
that plaintiff should have been given some means of ensuring that her application for 
20 
Section 8 benefits was received and given meaningful review). Federal form applicants 
21 
22  who submit their forms without DPOC therefore have a right to due process in how their 
23 
U.S. citizenship is investigated or assessed in the course of decisions as to whether they are 
24 
permitted to register to vote. 
25 
141.  The Citizenship Investigation Provisions established by HB 2492, particularly 
26 
the vague standard information that the applicant is not a United States citizen, create a 
27 
28 
60 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 63 of 68
high risk of erroneous deprivation, first, for the reasons described above in Count One and 
1 
2  second, because accurately matching two or more sets of data across different databases, 
3 
particularly those not designed to interact, is a difficult enterprise. Jurisdictions that have 
4 
attempted such matching schemes have struggled not only with stale data but also to ensure 
5 
that the person who is assertedly the voter found on a database is in fact the individual on 
6 
7  the voter list and not another individual who shares some personal information with the 
8 
voter.  
9 
142.  While  notice  is  given  to  registration  applicants  who  are  matched  to 
10 
information indicating they are not U.S. citizens, HB 2492 fails to give these individuals an 
11 
12  opportunity to affirm their citizenship or even to submit DPOC prior to the rejection and 
13 
reflexively refers the applicant to law enforcement for investigation. Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-
14 
121.01(E), as amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  4 (If the county recorder or other 
15 
officer in charge of elections matches the applicant with information that the applicant is not 
16 
17  a United States citizen, the county recorder or other officer in charge of elections shall reject 
18 
the application, notify the applicant that the application was rejected because the applicant 
19 
is not a United States citizen and forward the application to the county attorney and Attorney 
20 
General for investigation.). 
21 
22  143.  In order to be meaningful, the right to be heard must be afforded prior to the 
23 
deprivation. See Fuentes v. Shevin, 407 U.S. 67, 81-82 (1972) (If the right to notice and a 
24 
hearing is to serve its full purpose, then it is clear that it must be granted at a time when the 
25 
deprivation can still be prevented . . . the Court has traditionally insisted that, whatever its 
26 
form, opportunity for that hearing must be provided before the deprivation at issue takes 
27 
28 
61 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 64 of 68
effect.). HB 2492 fails to provide an opportunity to be heard prior to the denial of a 
1 
2  registration application, and thus does not comport with requirements of procedural due 
3 
process. 
4 
144.  No government interest exists that outweighs the risk of disenfranchisement 
5 
faced by federal form applicants who are matched to non-citizenship information. 
6 
7  145.  At all relevant times, Defendants have acted under color of state law. For the 
8 
foregoing reasons, Defendants have violated and will continue to violate procedural due 
9 
process, as guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C. 
10 
 1983. 
11 
12  COUNT SIX 
(Poder Latinx) 
13  (Violation of NVRA Requirement That States Accept and Use Timely-Submitted 
Federal Registration Forms to Register Voters, 52 U.S.C.  20505, 20507(a)) 
14  HB 2492 Section 5 (Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-123, 16-121.01(A)) 
 
15 
146.  The factual allegations contained in paragraphs 1 through 145 are incorporated 
16 
into Count Six, as though fully set forth herein.  
17 
147.  Section 6 of the NVRA requires covered States, including Arizona, to accept 
18 
19  and use the federal voter registration form for registration to vote in elections for federal 
20 
office. 52 U.S.C.  20505; Arizona v. Inter Tribal Council of Arizona, Inc. (ITCA), 570 U.S. 
21 
1 (2013). 
22 
148.  The documentary proof of residence requirement in HB 2492 as applied to the 
23 
24  federal voter registration form violates the NVRA under the U.S. Supreme Courts decision 
25 
in ITCA. 
26 
149.  Specifically, the Supreme Court concluded that the NVRA prohibits states 
27 
from applying different or additional requirements, such as the State of Arizonas proof of 
28 
62 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 65 of 68
citizenship requirement, to the federal voter registration form as promulgated by the Election 
1 
2  Assistance Commission. ITCA, 570 U.S. at 20 (We hold that [52 U.S.C.  20505] precludes 
3 
Arizona from requiring a Federal Form applicant to submit information beyond that required 
4 
by the form itself.). 
5 
150.  Because the federal form does not require documentary proof of residence, 
6 
7  HB 2492s attempt to require such proof of individuals registering to vote in elections for 
8 
federal office with the federal registration form violates the NVRA. 
9 
151.  Defendant Hobbs was notified of this violation of Section 6 of the NVRA on 
10 
June 3, 2022. See Exhibit A. As HB 2492 is still set to go into effect on January 1, 2023, this 
11 
12  violation has not been corrected. 
13 
152.  At all relevant times, Defendants have acted under color of state law. 
14 
153.  Defendants have violated and will continue to violate Sections 6 and 8 of the 
15 
NVRA and 42 U.S.C.  1983.  
16 
17 
I.  PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
18 
Plaintiffs respectfully request that this Court:  
19 
20    (a) Assume jurisdiction over this matter; 
21 
(b) Declare that the Citizenship Investigation Provisions of HB 2492 violate Section 
22 
8(b) of the National Voter Registration Act, 52 U.S.C.  20507(b), facially and as applied; 
23 
(c) Declare that Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(H) in HB 2243 violates 52 U.S.C.  
24 
25  10101(a)(2)(A) and the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments prohibition on racial and 
26  national origin discrimination; 
27 
28 
63 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 66 of 68
(d) Declare that the Citizenship Investigation Provisions of HB 2492 and HB 2243, 
1 
2  specifically Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-121.01(D), 16-121.01(E), and 16-121.01(F), as amended 
3 
by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  4, Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-143, as amended by 2022 Ariz. 
4 
Sess. Laws, ch. 99  7, Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(A)(10), as enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. 
5 
Laws, ch. 99  8, as further amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 370  2, and Ariz. Rev. 
6 
7  Stat.  16-165(F), 16-165(G), 16-165(H), 16-165(I), 16-165(J), as enacted by 2022 Ariz. 
8 
Sess. Laws, ch. 370  2, violate the Fourteenth Amendments Equal Protection and Due 
9 
Process Clauses, facially and as applied; 
10 
(e) Issue preliminary and permanent injunctions barring Defendants, their agents, and 
11 
12  successors from enforcing or acting under the authority granted in the Citizenship Provisions 
13 
of HB 2492 and HB 2243, specifically Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-121.01(D), 16-121.01(E), 16-
14 
121.01(F), as amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  4, Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-143, as 
15 
amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  7, Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(A)(10), as enacted 
16 
17  by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 99  8, as further amended by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 370 
18 
 2, and Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-165(F), 16-165(G), 16-165(H), 16-165(I), 16-165(J), as 
19 
enacted by 2022 Ariz. Sess. Laws, ch. 370  2; 
20 
  (f) Declare that the documentary proof of residence (DPOR) requirement contained 
21 
22  in HB 2492, specifically Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-123, 16-121.01(A), violates the National 
23 
Voter Registration Act, 52 U.S.C.  20505 & 20507(a); 
24 
  (g)  Issue preliminary and permanent injunctions barring Defendants, their agents, 
25 
and  successors  from  enforcing  or  acting  under  the  authority  granted  by  the  DPOR 
26 
requirement in Ariz. Rev. Stat.  16-123, 16-121.01(A); 
27 
28 
64 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 106   Filed 09/06/22   Page 67 of 68
  (h) Grant Plaintiffs their reasonable costs and attorneys fees incurred in bringing this 
1 
2  action pursuant to 42 U.S.C.  1988, 28 U.S.C.  1920, and as otherwise permitted by law; 
3 
and 
4 
  (i) Grant such other relief as this Court deems just and proper. 
5 
6    DATED this 6th day of September, 2022.

1  BACKGROUND 
 
2 
  Arizona recently enacted two laws amending several sections of the state election 
3 
laws.  HB 2243 and HB 2492 (the AZ Laws) were passed as part of Arizonas effort to 
4 
improve election integrity by ensuring voter qualifications are enforced and voter rolls are 
5 
6  accurate.  HB 2492 updates voter qualifications and the state voter registration form.  First, it 
7 
expands  the  citizenship  qualification  by  adding  satisfactory  evidence  of  citizenship  as 
8 
prescribed in Section 16-166.  A.R.S.  16-101(A)(1).  Such evidence must be submitted 
9 
10  with the state application for voter registration and includes the applicants driver license or 
11 
nonoperating  identification  license  number;  [a]  legible  photocopy  of  either  a  birth 
12 
certificate or U.S. passport; the applicants United States naturalization documents or the 
13 
number of the certificate of naturalization; or [t]he applicants bureau of Indian affairs card 
14 
15  number, tribal treaty card number or tribal enrollment number.  A.R.S. 16-166(F).  An 
16 
applicant  who  provides  satisfactory  proof  is  a  qualified  elector  and  will  have  their 
17 
registration processed by the appropriate state election official.  A.R.S.  16-121 (defining 
18 
19  qualified elector as [a] person who is qualified to register to vote . . . and who is properly 
20 
registered to vote . . . is at least eighteen years of age on or before the date of the election and 
21 
has provided satisfactory evidence of citizenship).   
22 
HB 2492 provides that proof of residence is also required, and can be satisfied by 
23 
24 
providing a valid form of identification that bears the photograph, name and address of the 
25 
elector, or [t]wo different items that contain the name and address of the elector, such as 
26 
a utility bill, a bank or credit union statement, Arizona vehicle registration, an Arizona 
27 
28 
 
1 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 9 of 25
 
1  vehicle insurance card, an Indian census card, tribal enrollment card or other form of tribal 
2 
identification.  A.R.S.  16-579(A)(1).   
3 
HB 2492 further provides that failure to include proof of citizenship on a state voter 
4 
registration form is grounds for the application to be rejected by the county recorder.  A.R.S. 
5 
6  16-121.01(C)  (Except  for  a  form  produced  by  the  United  States  Election  Assistance 
7 
Commission, . . . the . . . officer in charge of elections shall reject any application for 
8 
registration that is not accompanied by satisfactory evidence of citizenship.).  The procedure 
9 
10  differs, however, for applicants who use a form produced by the U.S. Election Assistance 
11 
Commission (EAC), commonly known as the Federal Form, because that procedure is 
12 
subject to the limitations of the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA).  The NVRAs 
13 
mandate that states accept and use the Federal Form precludes Arizona from requesting that 
14 
15  applicants  submit  documentary  proof  of  citizenship  because  the  Federal  Form  does  not 
16 
require it.  Arizona v. Inter Tribal Council of Arizona, Inc., 570 U.S. 1 (2013) (hereinafter 
17 
ITAC).  Election officials, however, are not barred from denying registration to those whose 
18 
19  ineligibility is established based on information in the officials possession, id. at 15, and 
20 
nothing in ITAC or the NVRA makes states presume the truth of any assertion an applicant 
21 
makes on the Federal Form, or bars states from verifying information provided on that form.  
22 
Thus, unlike the pre-empted law in ITAC, HB 2492 does not order election officials to reject a 
23 
24 
Federal Form outright if it does not include documentary proof of citizenship.  Instead, if 
25 
after  us[ing]  all  available  resources,  a  Federal  Form  applicants  citizenship  status  is 
26 
confirmed, such applicant shall be properly registered.  A.R.S.  16-121.01(E).  If the state 
27 
28  official comes to possess information that the applicant is not a United States citizen, the 
 
2 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 10 of 25
 
1  Federal Form application must be rejected and the applicant notified that he or she was 
2 
rejected because he or she was not a citizen.  Id.  Finally, if an election official is unable to 
3 
match the applicant with appropriate citizenship information, the applicant will be notified 
4 
that his or her citizenship could not be verified and that he or she will not be qualified to 
5 
6  vote in a presidential election or by mail with an early ballot in any election until satisfactory 
7 
evidence of citizenship is provided.  Id.   
8 
  HB 2243 provides the requirements for the state registration form discussed by HB 
9 
10  2492 and updates Arizonas procedures for ensuring current and accurate voter rolls.  A.R.S. 
11 
 16-165.  The provision enumerates the reasons why a voters registration may be cancelled, 
12 
including but not limited to, when the county recorder obtains information . . . and confirms 
13 
that the person registered is not a United States citizen[.]  A.R.S.  16-165(A)(10).  Before 
14 
15  such persons registration can be cancelled, the election official is required to provide written 
16 
notice stating that the persons registration will be canceled in thirty five days unless the 
17 
person provides satisfactory evidence of citizenship[.]  Id.  The notice must include a list of 
18 
19  documents the person may provide to establish his or her citizenship as well as a postage 
20 
prepaid  preaddressed  return  envelope.    Id.    Registration  will  thus  only  be  cancelled 
21 
following written notice and an opportunity to establish eligibility.  Furthermore, once a 
22 
registration  is  cancelled,  written  notice  is  again  provided  to  the  person  explaining  the 
23 
24 
cancellation and including instructions on how to register to vote if and when the person is 
25 
qualified.  A.R.S.  16-165(K).

1  ARGUMENT 
 
2 
The right to vote has long been recognized as a fundamental right of U.S. citizens.  
3 
See, e.g., Illinois Bd. of Elections v. Socialist Workers Party, 440 U.S. 173, 184 (1979) 
4 
([V]oting  is  of  the  most  fundamental  significance  under  our  constitutional  structure); 
5 
6  Wesberry v. Sanders, 376 U.S. 1, 17 (1964) (explaining that [o]ther rights, even the most 
7 
basic, are illusory if the right to vote is undermined.); Yick Wo v. Hopkins, 118 U.S. 356, 370 
8 
(1886)  (describing  the  right  to  vote  as  preservative  of  all  rights.);  see  also  Foley  v. 
9 
10  Connelie, 435 U.S. 291, 296 (1978) (recognizing the right[] of the people to be governed by 
11 
their  citizen  peers).    The  fundamental  nature  of  the  right  to  vote  requires  rules  and 
12 
regulations to ensure fairness and faith in elections.  See Storer v. Brown, 415 U.S. 724, 730 
13 
(1974)  (explaining  that  as  a  practical  matter,  there  must  be  a  substantial  regulation  of 
14 
15  elections if they are to be fair and honest and if some sort of order, rather than chaos, is to 
16 
accompany the democratic processes.); Buckley v. Am. Constitutional Law Found., 525 U.S. 
17 
182, 206 (1999) (States, of course, must regulate their elections to ensure that they are 
18 
19  conducted in a fair and orderly fashion.); Crawford v. Marion County Elec. Bd., 553 U.S. 
20 
181, 189 (2008) (explaining that public confidence in the integrity of the electoral process . . 
21 
. encourages citizen participation in the democratic process.).   
22 
The  Constitution  vests  the  authority  to  set  voter  qualifications  and  rules  for  the 
23 
24 
conduct  of  elections  primarily  in  the  states.    Article  I  of  the  Constitution  contains  the 
25 
guidelines for congressional elections, providing that [t]he House of Representatives1 shall 
26 
27                                                             
1 The election of Senators is covered by the Seventeenth Amendment, which provides that 
28 
[t]he Senate of the United States shall be composed of two Senators from each state, elected 
 
4 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 12 of 25
 
1  be composed of Members chosen every second Year by the People of the several States, and 
2 
the Electors in each State shall have the Qualifications requisite for Electors of the most 
3 
numerous Branch of the State Legislature.  U.S. Const. Art. I,  2, cl. 1 (the Qualifications 
4 
Clause).  Article I also authorizes state legislatures to determine [t]he times, places and 
5 
6  manner of holding elections for Senators and Representatives.  U.S. Const., Art. I,  4.  
7 
Unlike voter qualifications, Times, Places and Manner authority is not solely reserved to the 
8 
states.  The Constitution grants Congress the authority to make or alter such [state enacted] 
9 
10  regulations.  U.S. Const. art. 1,  4, cl. 1 (the Elections Clause).  
11 
The  authority  over  presidential  elections  is  also  primarily  delegated  to  the  states.  
12 
Article II provides that the states shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof 
13 
may  direct,  a  Number  of  Electors,  equal  to  the  whole  Number  of  Senators  and 
14 
15  Representatives  to  which  the  State  may  be  entitled  in  Congress:  but  no  Senator  or 
16 
Representative . . . shall be appointed an Elector.  U.S. Const., Art. II,  1, cl. 4 (the 
17 
Presidential Electors Clause).  Unlike Congresss Time, Place and Manner authority over 
18 
19  congressional elections, the constitution only authorizes Congress to determine the Time of 
20 
chusing the Electors, and the Day on which they shall give their Votes.  Id..  Congress 
21 
therefore  has  no  say  in  the  manner  or  qualifications  for  presidential  elections.    See 
22 
Oregon v. Mitchell, 400 U.S. 112, 210 (1970) (Harlan, J., concurring in part and dissenting in 
23 
24 
part) (It is difficult to see how words could be clearer in stating what Congress can control 
25 
26 
                                                                                                                                                                                                    
27  by the people thereof, . . . . The electors in each state shall have the qualifications requisite for 
electors of the most numerous branch of the state legislatures. 
28 
 
 
5 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 13 of 25
 
1  and what it cannot control.  Surely nothing in these provisions lends itself to the view that 
2 
voting qualifications in federal elections are to be set by Congress.).   
3 
Thus, while Congresss authority under the Elections Clause to enact Time, Place and 
4 
Manner laws is broad, it has no authority to set voter qualifications.  See Husted v. A. Philip 
5 
6  Randolph Inst., 138 S. Ct. 1833, 1859 (2018) (explaining that Congresss authority over the 
7 
Times, Places and Manner of congressional elections is paramount, and may be exercised at 
8 
any time, and to any extent which it deems expedient; and so far as it is exercised . . . the 
9 
10  regulations effected supersede any conflicting state laws.).  See also ITAC, 570 U.S. at 16 
11 
(explaining that Congress has the constitutional authority to regulate how federal elections 
12 
are held, but not who may vote in them.) (emphases in original). 
13 
I.  THE  AZ  LAWS  DO  NOT  VIOLATE  THE  NATIONAL  VOTER 
14 
REGISTRATION ACT. 
15   
  Neither  ITAC  nor  the  NVRA  should  be  read  to  infringe  states  constitutional 
16 
17  authority over voter qualifications in federal elections, nor to bar states from performing their 
18 
constitutional duty to safeguard election integrity.  Nothing in these authorities makes states 
19 
presume the truth of any assertion an applicant makes on the Federal Form, forbids states to 
20 
21  verify  assertions  made  on  that  form,  compels  states  to  accept  assertions  that  cannot  be 
22 
verified, or precludes states from establishing their own election procedures or purging their 
23 
voter rolls of ineligible voters. 
24 
A. The AZ Laws do not conflict with the NVRAs requirement that states 
25 
accept and use the Federal Form. 
26   
Congress enacted the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 (NVRA), 52 U.S.C.  
27 
28  20501 et seq., based on its broad authority under the Elections Clause.  The NVRA was 
 
6 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 14 of 25
 
1  passed to increase the number of eligible citizens who register to vote for Federal office, 
2 
and protect the integrity of the electoral process.  52 U.S.C.  20501(b)(3) (emphasis 
3 
added).  See also Husted, 138 S. Ct. at 1838 (The Act has two main objectives: increasing 
4 
voter registration and removing ineligible persons from the States voter registration rolls.).  
5 
6  The  NVRA  accomplishes  these  objectives  by  requir[ing]  States  to  provide  simplified 
7 
systems for registering to vote in federal elections.  ITAC, 570 U.S. at 6 (quoting Young v. 
8 
Fordice, 520 U.S. 273, 275 (1997)). 
9 
10  A key part of this simplified system is the National Mail Registration Form, also 
11 
known as the Federal Form.  52 U.S.C.  20505.  The NVRA requires that [e]ach State 
12 
accept  and  use  the  Federal  Form  for  voter  registration.    52  U.S.C.    20505(a)(1).  
13 
Accordingly, a state-imposed requirement of evidence of citizenship not required by the 
14 
15  Federal Form is inconsistent with the NVRAs mandate that States accept and use the 
16 
Federal Form.  ITAC, 570 U.S. at 15.  This requirement, however, does not preclude States 
17 
from  deny[ing]  registration  based  on  information  in  their  possession  establishing  the 
18 
19  applicants ineligibility.  The NVRA clearly contemplates that not every submitted Federal 
20 
Form will result in registration.  Id. 
21 
The AZ Laws are in compliance with the NVRA and  ITAC because they do not 
22 
interfere with Arizonas acceptance and use of the Federal Form.  First, Arizona does not 
23 
24 
require Federal Form  applicants  to submit evidence  of citizenship or residence with the 
25 
Federal Form; such requirements are only applicable to the state registration form.  HB 2492 
26 
requires  automatic  rejection  of  applications  submitted  without  evidence  of  citizenship, 
27 
28  [e]xcept for [applications submitted via] a form produced by the United States Election 
 
7 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 15 of 25
 
1  Assistance Commission.  A.R.S.  16-121.01(C).  With respect to the Federal Form, election 
2 
officials are instructed to use all available resources to verify the citizenship status of the 
3 
[Federal Form] applicant.  Id.  Such resources include but are not limited to databases for the 
4 
Department  of  Transportation,  Social  Security  Administration,  and  the  United  States 
5 
6  Citizenship and Immigration Service Systematic Alien Verification for Entitlements Program.  
7 
Id.  If citizenship cannot be verified based on this information, the election official must 
8 
provide  written notice that  the applicant  will not be qualified  to vote in a presidential 
9 
10  election  or  by  mail  with  an  early  ballot  in  any  election  until  satisfactory  evidence  of 
11 
citizenship is provided.  A.R.S.  16-121.01(E). 
12 
These verification procedures do not conflict with the mandate that states accept and 
13 
use the Federal Form.  If that mandate forbade states to verify assertions made on the 
14 
15  Federal Form, it would require states to presume the truth of those assertions.  Any such 
16 
presumption would be nonsensical, and trench on states powers to establish and maintain 
17 
voter qualifications. And no such presumption of truth is required by the accept and use 
18 
19  mandate, since states retain the ability not to register applicants who are found ineligible 
20 
based on information not submitted with the Federal Form.  ITAC, 570 U.S. at 15.   
21 
And if states may verify assertions made on the form, and not register applicants 
22 
whose assertions are found false, the accept and use mandate also does not forbid states to 
23 
24 
act on their inability to verify an applicants assertions by not registering that applicant.  If 
25 
states had to register voters whose qualifications could not be verified, their constitutional 
26 
powers over voter qualifications would be severely compromised. See ITAC, 570 U.S. at 16 
27 
28 
 
8 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 16 of 25
 
1  (explaining that states, not Congress, have the constitutional authority to regulate . . . who 
2 
may vote in federal elections) (emphasis in original). 
3 
B. States  retain  the  power  to  create  and  use  their  own  mail-in  voter 
4  registration forms under the NVRA. 
 
5 
As the Supreme Court has explained, [a] State has a compelling interest in preserving 
6 
the integrity of the election process.  Purcell v. Gonzalez, 549 U.S. 1, 4 (2006) (quoting Eu 
7 
8  v. San Francisco County Democratic Central Comm., 489 U.S. 214, 231 (1989)).  The Court 
9 
went on to state that [c]onfidence in the integrity of our electoral processes is essential to the 
10 
functioning of our participatory democracy.  Voter fraud drives honest citizens out of the 
11 
democratic process and breeds distrust of our government.  Voters who fear their legitimate 
12 
13 
votes will be outweighed by fraudulent ones will feel disenfranchised.  Id.  The AZ Laws 
14 
serve this purpose by ensuring that only eligible voters are registered to participate in the 
15 
electoral process.   
16 
17  While it is true that Arizona must accept and use the Federal Form, the NVRA 
18 
permits states to develop and use a mail voter registration form that meets all of the criteria 
19 
stated in section 9(b)[.]  52 U.S.C.  20505 (a)(2).  As noted by the Supreme Court, while 
20 
21  the NVRA imposes certain mandates on states, describing those mandates in detail[,] it 
22 
still leaves [the states] room for policy choice.  Young v. Fordice, 520 U.S. 273, 286 
23 
(1997).   
24 
Arizonas policy choice to require evidence of citizenship on its state mail voter 
25 
26  registration form is within the bounds of the NVRA.  First, the NVRA provides what a mail 
27 
registration form may require . . . to assess the eligibility of the applicant.  52 U.S.C.  
28 
 
9 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 17 of 25
 
1  20508(b)(1)  (emphasis  added).    But  [t]he  NVRA  does  not  list,  for  example,  all  other 
2 
information the State mayor may notprovide or request.  Young, 520 U.S. at 286.  
3 
Because  Section  9(b)  does  not  contain  any  prohibitions  on  requiring  that  documentary 
4 
evidence be submitted in conjunction with a mail voter registration, states are free to require 
5 
6  such information.  Accordingly, the fact that the Federal Form does not require documentary 
7 
proof of citizenship does not preclude states from requiring such information on their own 
8 
forms. 
9 
10  Next the NVRA indicates what mail registration forms must contain.  It provides that 
11 
the registration form shall include a statement that specifies each eligibility requirement 
12 
(including citizenship); contains an attestation that the applicant meets such requirement; and 
13 
requires the signature of the applicant, under penalty of perjury.  52 U.S.C.  20508(b)(2) 
14 
15  (emphases added).  The only prohibition is found in subsection (b)(3), which provides that the 
16 
registration  form  may  not  include  any  requirement  for  notarization  or  other  formal 
17 
authentication.  52 U.S.C.  20508(b)(3).  The Arizona mail voter registration form does not 
18 
19  violate any of these provisions. 
20 
Additionally, the Supreme Court was clear in ITAC that state-developed forms may 
21 
require information the Federal Form does not.  ITAC, 570 U.S. at 12.  Therefore, under the 
22 
NVRA, States retain the flexibility to design and use their own registration forms.  Id.  
23 
24 
Thus, Arizona is free to require more information on and documentary evidence with its own 
25 
mail registration form than is required by the Federal Form.  Id.  The purpose of the Federal 
26 
Form is to provide a simple, streamlined method for voter registration, not to interfere with 
27 
28  the states authority to conduct elections. 
 
10 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 18 of 25
 
1  C. The NVRA does not prevent the states from purging ineligible voters 
from the voter rolls. 
2 
 
The NVRA requires that states conduct a general program that makes a reasonable 
3 
4  effort to remove the names of ineligible voters from the official lists of eligible voters by 
5 
reason of the death of the registrant; or a change in address of the registrant.  52 U.S.C.  
6 
20507(a)(4).    It  further  provides  examples  of  how  states  may  conduct  these  programs, 
7 
8  including the requirement that such programs to be completed not later than 90 days prior to 
9 
the date of a primary or general election for Federal office.  52 U.S.C.  20507(c).  Finally, 
10 
names are not to be removed for change of residence reasons absent written confirmation of 
11 
an address change or failure to respond to written notice combined with failure to vote.  52 
12 
13 
U.S.C.  20507(d).   
14 
HB 2243 complies with these requirements.  Because the NVRA does not prohibit the 
15 
states from removing voters based on ineligibility, Arizona is free to remove persons it has 
16 
17  determined are not U.S. citizens.  
18 
II. PLAINTIFFS  CONSTITUTIONAL  CLAIMS  SHOULD  BE  DISMISSED 
19  BECAUSE THEY FAIL THE ANDERSON-BURDICK TEST. 
 
20 
As explained above, the right of citizens to vote is fundamental.  This fundamental 
21 
right encompasses more than just the ability to cast ones vote; equal participation among 
22 
citizens is also guaranteed.  See Dunn v. Blumstein, 405 U.S. 330, 336 (1972) (explaining that 
23 
24  a citizen has a constitutionally protected right to participate in elections on an equal basis 
25 
with other citizens in the jurisdiction.); Bush v. Gore, 531 U.S. 98, 104 (2000) (The right to 
26 
vote is protected in more than the initial allocation of the franchise.  Equal protection applies 
27 
28  as well to the manner of exercise.).  See also Wesberry, 376 U.S. at 17 (explaining that 
 
11 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 19 of 25
 
1  [o]ur constitution leaves no room for classification of people in a way that unnecessarily 
2 
abridges this right.).  Although the States have broad constitutional authority to regulate who 
3 
may vote and how they may do so, the State may not, by later arbitrary and disparate 
4 
treatment, value one persons vote over that of another.  Bush, 531 U.S. at 104-05. 
5 
6  The Supreme Court applies what is known as the Anderson-Burdick framework when 
7 
analyzing whether a states election law violates due process or equal protection.  See Dudum 
8 
v. Arntz, 640 F.3d 1098, 1106 n.15 (9th Cir. 2011) (explaining that [t]he Supreme Court has 
9 
10  addressed such claims collectively using a single analytic framework.).  The Ninth Circuit 
11 
explained that [w]hen the burdens on voting imposed by the government are severe, strict 
12 
scrutiny applies . . . . But voting regulations are rarely subjected to strict scrutiny.  Id. at 
13 
1106.  Such non-severe lesser burdens on voting are subject to less exacting review, and a 
14 
15  States  important  regulatory  interest  will  usually  be  enough  to  justify  reasonable, 
16 
nondiscriminatory restrictions.  Id. 
17 
Because [e]lection laws will invariably impose some burden upon individual voters, 
18 
19  the standard of review is flexible.   Burdick v. Takushi, 504 U.S. 428, 433-34 (1992).  
20 
Accordingly, the reviewing court must weigh the character and magnitude of the asserted 
21 
injury to the rights protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments that the plaintiff seeks 
22 
to vindicate against the precise interests put forward by the State as justifications for the 
23 
24 
burden imposed by its rule, taking into consideration the extent to which those interests make 
25 
it necessary to burden the plaintiff's rights.  Id. at 434 (citation and internal quotation marks 
26 
omitted).  See also Crawford, 553 U.S. at 190 (We reaffirmed Andersons requirement that a 
27 
28  court evaluating a constitutional challenge to an election regulation weigh the asserted injury 
 
12 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 20 of 25
 
1  to the right to vote against the precise interests put forward by the State as justifications for 
2 
the burden imposed by this rule.) (citation omitted).   
3 
The  key  question  is  whether  the  burden  is  severe  or  reasonable  [and] 
4 
nondiscriminatory.  Burdick, 504 U.S. at 434.  Where the burden imposed by a state election 
5 
6  law is severe, strict scrutiny applies.  See Short v. Brown, 893 F.3d 671, 677 (9th Cir. 2018) 
7 
(explaining that the Constitution permits states to impose some burdens on voters through 
8 
election regulations, and it requires strict scrutiny of those regulations only where the burden 
9 
10  imposed is severe.).  As the Supreme Court has explained, because a government has such 
11 
a compelling interest in securing the right to vote freely and effectively, this Court never has 
12 
held a State to the burden of demonstrating empirically the objective effects on political 
13 
stability that [are] produced by the voting regulation in question.  Burson v. Freeman, 504 
14 
15  U.S. 191, 210 (1992) (quoting Munro v. Socialist Workers Party, 479 U.S. 189, 195 (1986)). 
16 
HB 2492 contains burdens for applicants that are minimal and thus do not warrant 
17 
strict  scrutiny.    See  Crawford,  553  U.S.  at  205  (Scalia,  J.,  concurring)  (Ordinary  and 
18 
19  widespread burdens, such as those requiring nominal effort of everyone, are not severe.).  
20 
The Crawford court held that voter ID requirements for in person voting survived Anderson-
21 
Burdick review, explaining that the inconvenience of obtaining the required documents 
22 
surely does not qualify as a substantial burden.  Id. at 198.  HB 2492 provides applicants 
23 
24 
with several options to establish residency and citizenship, including but not limited to state 
25 
identification cards, utility bills, and tribal enrollment cards.   
26 
Because the burdens imposed by the AZ Laws are not severe, the court need only 
27 
28  determine whether the states interest is sufficient to justify the regulation.  Timmons v. Twin 
 
13 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 21 of 25
 
1  Cities Area New Party, 520 U.S. 351, 358 (1997) (Lesser burdens . . . trigger less exacting 
2 
review,  and  a  States  important  regulatory  interest  will  usually  be  enough  to  justify 
3 
reasonable, nondiscriminatory restrictions.).  See also, Obama for Am. v. Husted, 697 F.3d 
4 
423, 428-30 (6th Cir. 2012) (explaining that the courts must weigh the burden on voters 
5 
6  against the states asserted justifications and make the hard judgment that our adversary 
7 
system demands.) (citation omitted).  The Supreme Court has recognized that [a] State 
8 
indisputably has a compelling interest in preserving the integrity of its election process.  
9 
10  Purcell, 549 U.S. at 4.  See also Brnovich v. Democratic Nat'l Comm., 141 S. Ct. 2321, 2340 
11 
(2021) (listing prevention of fraud and [e]nsuring every vote is cast freely as important 
12 
state  interests).    The  Anderson-Burdick  standard  is  satisfied  because  the  AZ  Laws  are 
13 
reasonably related to Arizonas interests in securing free and fair elections in the state.  
14 
15  Additionally, the AZ Laws would survive even if the Court determined that traditional 
16 
equal protection analysis should be applied instead of the Anderson-Burdick test.  There is no 
17 
equal protection violation where a law is neutral on its face and rationally may be said to 
18 
19  serve a purpose the Government is constitutionally empowered to pursue.  Washington v. 
20 
Davis, 426 U.S. 229, 246 (1976).  The AZ Laws were enacted to advance the important state 
21 
interest of protecting the integrity of state and federal elections.  News Release, Rep. Jake 
22 
Hoffman  (Mar.  30,  2022), 
23 
24 
https://www.azleg.gov/press/house/55LEG/2R/220330HOFFMANHB2492.pdf  (describing 
25 
HB 2492 as a giant step toward ensuring elections are easy, convenient, and secure in our 
26 
state.).  See also Democratic Natl Comm. v. Reagan, 2018 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 77690, at *58 
27 
28 
 
14 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 22 of 25
 
1  (D. Ariz. May 8, 2018) (Fraud prevention and preserving public confidence in election 
2 
integrity are facially important state regulatory interests.).  As the Supreme Court explained, 
3 
[t]here is no question about the legitimacy or importance of the 
4  States  interest  in  counting  only  the  votes  of  eligible  voters.  
Moreover,  the  interest  in  orderly  administration  and  accurate 
5 
recordkeeping  provides  a  sufficient  justification  for  carefully 
6  identifying all voters participating in the election process.  While 
the most effective method of preventing election fraud may well 
7 
be debatable, the propriety of doing so is perfectly clear. 
8   
Crawford, 553 U.S. at 196. 
9 
10  Finally,  Plaintiffs  discriminatory  purpose  equal  protection  claims  also  must  fail.  
11 
While true that [a] facially neutral law . . . warrants strict scrutiny . . . if it can be proved that 
12 
the law was motivated by a racial purpose or object[,] Hunt v. Cromartie, 526 U.S. 541, 546 
13 
(1999)  (internal  quotation  marks  omitted),  Plaintiffs  complaints  contain  no  evidence  of 
14 
15  improper racial motivation.  Under the Arlington Heights standard, [d]etermining whether 
16 
invidious discriminatory purpose was a motivating factor demands a sensitive inquiry into 
17 
such circumstantial and direct evidence as may be available.  Vill. of Arlington Heights v. 
18 
19  Metro Hous. Dev. Corp., 429 U.S. 252, 266) (1977).  While [d]isproportionate impact is not 
20 
irrelevant . . . it is not the sole touchstone of an invidious racial discrimination.  Proof of 
21 
racially  discriminatory  intent  or  purpose  is  required  to  show  a  violation  of  the  Equal 
22 
Protection Clause.  Id. at 264-65 (internal citation and quotation marks omitted).  Here, the 
23 
24 
absence  of  proof  of  discriminatory  intent  forecloses  any  claim  that  the  official  action 
25 
challenged in this case violates the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  
26 
Memphis v. Greene, 451 U.S. 100, 119 (1981).   
27 
28 
 
15 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 23 of 25
 
1  According  to  the  Supreme  Court,  [d]iscriminatory  purpose  .  .  .  implies  that  the 
2 
decisionmaker . . . selected . . . a particular course of action at least in part because of, of, 
3 
not merely in spite of, its adverse effects upon an identifiable group.  Hernandez v. New 
4 
York, 500 U.S. 352, 360 (1991) (quoting Personnel Administrator of Mass. v. Feeney, 442 
5 
6  U.S.  256,  279  (1979)).    Arlington  Heights  supplies  examples  of  how  to  establish 
7 
discriminatory intent, yet Plaintiffs various complaints do not contain any such evidence.  
8 
Vill. of Arlington Heights, 429 U.S. at 266-68 (examples include but are not limited to[t]he 
9 
10  impact  of  the  official  action;  [t]he  historical  background  of  the  decision;  and  [t]he 
11 
legislative or administrative history).  Indeed, the bill had the opposite intent, to ensure 
12 
fairness to all Arizona residents and prevent election fraud.  News Release, Office of the 
13 
Governor,  Mar.  30,  2022,  https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2022/03/governor-ducey-
14 
15  signs-legislation-furthering-arizonas-position-leader-election (stating that [e]lection integrity 
16 
means counting every lawful vote and prohibiting any attempt to illegally cast a vote.).  
17 
Plaintiffs constitutional claims must be dismissed because they fail to provide evidence of 
18 
19  discriminatory purpose.  
20 
 
21 
 
22 
 
23 
24 
 
25 
 
26 
 
27 
28   
 
16 
   

Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 131-1   Filed 09/22/22   Page 24 of 25
 
1  CONCLUSION 
 
2    For  the  foregoing  reasons,  Defendants  consolidated  motion  to  dismiss  should  be 
3 
granted. 
4 
September 22, 2022       _/s/ Gina M. DAndrea

documents.title: Order
documents.text:
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 1 of 9
 
 
 
1   
2   
3   
4   
5   
6  IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
7  FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
 
8 
 
9  Mi Familia Vota, et al.,  No. CV-22-00509-PHX-SRB 
   
10  Plaintiffs,  ORDER  
   
11  v.  
 
12  Adrian Fontes, et al., 
 
13  Defendants. 
 
14   
15    In April 2023, the Speaker of the Arizona House of Representatives Ben Toma and 
16  President of the Arizona Senate Warren Petersen (collectively, the Legislators) moved 
17  and were granted leave to intervene as defendants in this case. (Doc. 348, Mot. to Intervene; 
18  Doc.  363,  04/26/2023  Order.)  The  Legislators  then  invoked  legislative  privilege  in 
19  response to Plaintiffs discovery requests. (See, e.g., Doc. 500-1, Ex. D.) Non-US Plaintiffs 
20  sought to compel discovery. (Doc. 502, Hrg. Tr. at 87:788:9.) The Court ordered the 
21  parties to submit simultaneous briefs on the issue of whether the legislative privilege 
22  applies, which the parties filed on August 2, 2023. (Doc. 499, Defs. Br.; Doc. 500, Pls. 
23  Br.; Hrg. Tr. at 87:788:20.)  
24  I.  PROCEDURAL HISTORY 
25  The history of this litigation is set out in the Courts previous Orders. (E.g., Doc. 
26  304, 02/15/2023 Order.) Plaintiffs claim that two recently enacted laws, H.B. 2243 and 
27  H.B. 2492 (the Voting Laws), are unlawful because they violate multiple federal laws 
28  and provisions of the Constitution.  (E.g., Doc. 67, LUCHA Compl.  32935; Doc. 1, 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 2 of 9
 
 
 
1  22-cv-1381,  AAANHPI  Compl.    14350.)  No  Plaintiff  named  the  Legislators  as 
2  defendants. (Pls. Br. at 1.) However, under Arizona law, both the Speaker and President 
3  are entitled to be heard [i]n any proceeding in which a state statute . . . is alleged to be 
4  unconstitutional.  A.R.S.   12-1841(A).  The  Speaker  and  the  President  may  in  their 
5  discretion either (1) intervene as a party, (2) file briefs in the lawsuit, or (3) choose not to 
6  participate in the lawsuit. Id.  12-1841(D). The Legislators moved to intervene in their 
7  official  capacities,  and  on  behalf  of  their  respective  legislative  chambers.  (Mot.  to 
8  Intervene at 4.) Plaintiffs assert that the Legislators have since invoked the legislative 
9  privilege to refuse to answer deposition questions regarding the enactment of the [Voting 
10  Laws], and . . . have objected to designating anyone to testify on behalf of their respective 
11  chambers under [Rule] 30(b)(6) despite intervening to defend the Voting Laws on the 
12  merits. (Pls. Br. at 13.)  
13  II.  LEGAL STANDARD & ANALYSIS 
14  Legislative immunity grants state legislators protection from criminal, civil, or 
15  evidentiary process that interferes with their legitimate legislative activity. Puente Ariz. 
16  v. Arpaio, 314 F.R.D. 664, 669 (D. Ariz. 2016) (quoting Tenney v. Brandhove, 341 U.S. 
17  367, 376 (1951)); Sup. Ct. of Va. v. Consumers Union of U.S., Inc., 446 U.S. 719, 732 
18  (1980) (explaining that the legislative immunity of state legislators is similar in origin and 
19  rationale to that of Congresspeople). The legislative privilege, a corollary to legislative 
20  immunity, is a qualified privilege that shields legislators from compulsory evidentiary 
21  process. Mi Familia Vota v. Hobbs, -- F. Supp. 3d --, 2023 WL 4595824, at *4 (D. Ariz. 
22  July 18, 2023); see United States v. Gillock, 445 U.S. 360, 37073 (1980) (limiting the 
23  scope of the legislative privilege for state legislators where important federal interests are 
24  at stake, as in the enforcement of federal criminal statutes). The legislative privilege is 
25  personal to each legislator. Puente Ariz., 314 F.R.D. at 671. 
26  A.  The Legislators Waived the Legislative Privilege 
27  Plaintiffs  argue  that  the  Legislators  have  waived  their  legislative  privilege  by 
28  voluntarily intervening in this lawsuit and putting their intent at issue. (Pls. Br. at 57.) 
 
- 2 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 3 of 9
 
 
 
1  Plaintiffs direct the Court to Powell v. Ridge, in which plaintiffs sued the Pennsylvania 
2  governor and state officials claiming that the public education funding system was racially 
3  discriminatory. 247 F.3d 520, 522 (3d Cir. 2001). Leaders of the state legislature intervened 
4  in the lawsuit, citing their financial and legal interests in the litigation and the need to 
5  articulate to the Court the unique perspective of the legislative branch of the Pennsylvania 
6  government. Id. at 52223. The legislators explicitly concurred in the other defendants 
7  motion to dismiss but asserted the legislative privilege after the plaintiffs sought discovery. 
8  Id. at 523. The district court compelled discovery, after which the legislators appealed. Id. 
9  In dismissing the legislators interlocutory appeal for lack of jurisdiction, the Third Circuit 
10  explained that the legislators stray[ed] far beyond the bounds of traditional legislative 
11  immunity by fashioning a privilege which would allow them to continue to actively 
12  participate in [the] litigation by submitting briefs, motions, and discovery requests of their 
13  own, yet allow them to refuse to comply with, and most likely, appeal from every adverse 
14  order. Id. at 525. 
15  The  Legislators  argue  that  Powell  is  distinguishable  because  the  intervening 
16  defendants had no statutory authority to intervene, whereas the Legislators intervened 
17  in their official capacities pursuant to A.R.S.  12-1841(D) to present their views on the 
18  States interests. (Defs. Br. at 7.) This argument would allow the Arizona Legislature to 
19  exercise its self-created right to intervene yet shield its leaders from ever waiving the 
20  legislative privilege. Like the defendants in  Powell, the Legislators are not seeking 
21  immunity from this suit, but instead seek to actively participate in this litigation yet 
22  avoid the burden of discovery regarding their legislative activities. Powell, 247 F.3d at 525. 
23  Plaintiffs did not seek discovery from the Legislators until the Legislators sought to fully 
24  defend the laws passed by the legislature. (Mot. to Intervene at 4, 11.) The Legislators 
25  also specifically put their own motives for passing the Voting Laws at issue when denying 
26  Plaintiffs  allegations  that  the  Arizona  Legislature  enacted  the  Voting  Laws  with 
27  discriminatory intent. (Pls. Br. at 6; see, e.g., Doc. 348-1, Ex. A, Ans. to AAANHPI 
28  Compl.  at  1618    131,  14750,  (denying  allegations  that  the  Voting  Laws  are 
 
- 3 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 4 of 9
 
 
 
1  intentionally discriminatory); Doc. 348-1, Ex. A, Ans. to LUCHA Compl. at 98  33738 
2  (same).)  
3  The Legislators contend that they have not waived the privilege because their 
4  defense relies solely upon the publicly available legislative history materials instead of 
5  any  privileged  information  or  the  testimony  of  any  legislator  regarding  his  or  her 
6  consideration of or passage of the Voting Laws. (Defs. Br. at 46.) The Legislators cite 
7  Democratic National Committee v. Arizona Secretary of States Office, which considered 
8  whether political party and civic organization plaintiffs waived their First Amendment 
9  privilege by challenging state election laws. No. CV-16-01065-PHX-DLR, 2017 WL 
10  3149914, at *4 (D. Ariz. July 25, 2017). In finding that the plaintiffs had not waived the 
11  privilege, the court noted that the plaintiffs used only publicly available information to 
12  support their claims and that [t]he privileged information that the State Defendants 
13  [sought] evidently include[d] a substantial amount of proprietary predictive modeling and 
14  strategic communications, none of which go to the heart of the case or to the State 
15  Defendants defense. Id. at *45 (emphasis added).  
16  The Court is not persuaded by the Legislators argument. Though the Legislators 
17  avow[] to the Court that they will not rely on privileged information in support of their 
18  defense, the information sought in discovery does in fact go to the heart of Plaintiffs 
19  claims and the constitutionality of the Voting Laws. Id. at 5; (Defs. Br. at 6; see Plfs. Br. 
20  at 6.) Motive is often most easily discovered by examining the unguarded acts and 
21  statements of those who would otherwise attempt to conceal evidence of discriminatory 
22  intent. Harris v. Ariz. Indep. Redistricting Commn, 993 F. Supp. 2d 1042, 1071 (D. Ariz. 
23  2014) (quoting Cano v. Davis, 193 F. Supp. 2d 1177, 118182 (C.D. Cal. 2002) (Reinhardt, 
24  J., concurring in part and dissenting in part)). And contrary to the Legislators argument, 
25  the Court is not [a]pplying a blanket waiver of legislative privilege whenever Arizonas 
26  legislative leaders intervene under  12-1841(D), but instead finds that the Speaker and 
27  President each waived their privilege by intervening to fully defend the Voting Laws and 
28  putting their motives at issue. (See Defs. Br. at 3.)  
 
- 4 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 5 of 9
 
 
 
1  The Legislators assert that finding waiver would undermine the purpose of allowing 
2  for  legislative  participation  in  federal  lawsuits,  specifically,  that  [p]ermitting  the 
3  participation  of  lawfully  authorized  state  agents  promotes  informed  federal-court 
4  decisionmaking and avoids the risk of setting aside duly enacted state law based on an 
5  incomplete understanding of relevant state interests. (Id. at 23 (quoting Berger v. N.C. 
6  State Conf. of the NAACP, 142 S. Ct. 2191, 2202 (2022)). However, the Berger Court 
7  analyzed only whether legislative leaders possessed a legitimate interest to intervene in the 
8  lawsuit under Rule 24; the legislative privilege was not at issue. 142 S. Ct. at 220103 
9  ([F]ederal courts should rarely question that a States interests will be practically impaired 
10  or impeded if its duly authorized representatives are excluded from participating in federal 
11  litigation challenging state law.). But the legislative privileges animating purpose is to 
12  allow duly elected legislators to discharge their public duties without concern of adverse 
13  consequences outside the ballot box, and minimize[e] the distraction of diverting their 
14  time, energy, and attention from their legislative tasks to defend the litigation. Lee v. City 
15  of Los Angeles, 908 F.3d 1175, 1187 (9th Cir. 2018) (citation and internal quotation marks 
16  omitted) (cleaned up); Kay v. City of Rancho Palos Verdes, No. CV 0203922 MMM RZ, 
17  2003 WL 25294710, at *11 (C.D. Cal. Oct. 10, 2003) (indicating that the underlying 
18  policy  goal  of  the  privilege  is  to  protect[]  legislators  from  interference  with  their 
19  legislative  duties  (citation  omitted)).  [T]he  only  reasonable  inference  from  the 
20  Legislators litigation conduct is that they have decided to forego that protection in 
21  pursuit of an opportunity to defend in court their decisions as legislators . . . . Singleton v. 
22  Merrill, 576 F. Supp. 3d 931, 941 (N.D. Ala. 2021) (cleaned up) (observing that the 
23  intervening legislator defendants put in issue the very facts that they now assert their 
24  immunity covers). 
25  The Court finds that the Legislators have waived their legislative privilege.1 The 
26  Legislators must produce communications sent or received by either the Speaker or the 
27 
 
1 Because the Court finds that the Speaker and President have waived the legislative 
28 
privilege,  it  need  not  consider  Plaintiffs  argument  that  the  balance  of  factors  favor 
overcoming the privilege. (See Pls. Br. at 79.) 
 
- 5 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 6 of 9
 
 
 
1  President which have been withheld on legislative privilege grounds. Plaintiffs may also 
2  depose the Legislators about their personal perspectives of the Voting Laws legislative 
3  process. (See Pls. Br. at 23.) However, [t]he legislative privilege is a personal one, 
4  and the Speaker or President could not waive the privilege for their fellow legislators. 
5  Puente Ariz., 314 F.R.D. at 671 (quoting Marylanders for Fair Representation, Inc. v. 
6  Schaefer, 144 F.R.D. 292, 298 (D. Md. 1992)). To the extent Plaintiffs seek information 
7  held by other members of the Arizona Legislature, it remains protected by the legislative 
8  privilege.  
9  B.  Plaintiffs May Not Depose the Arizona Legislature as an Entity 
10  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 30(b)(6) permits a party to depose a public or 
11  private corporation, a partnership, an association, a governmental agency, or other entity, 
12  which then must designate one or more officers, directors, or managing agents . . . to 
13  testify on its behalf. Plaintiffs seek to depose the Arizona House of Representatives and 
14  the Arizona Senate and assert that the Speaker and the President have necessitated 
15  deposition testimony with respect to the legislature as an entity by intervening on behalf 
16  of their respective legislative chambers. (Pls. Br. at 910.) Specifically, Plaintiffs seek to 
17  depose  the  Arizona  Legislature  about  (1)  the  Legislatures  drafting,  introduction, 
18  amendment, passage, and enactment of the Voting Laws, (2) the Legislatures objectives, 
19  motives, and information considered when drafting and passing the Voting Laws, and (3) 
20  individual legislators communications with other legislators or third parties. (See Doc. 
21  499-1, Ex. 1, at 57.) The Legislators counter that Plaintiffs seek information protected by 
22  the legislative privilege and that a 30(b)(6) deposition is unworkable in terms of preparing 
23  and identifying a single witness who can present binding testimony on behalf of the 
24  Arizona Legislature. (Defs. Br. at 8.)  
25  The Court agrees with the Legislators that a 30(b)(6) deposition of the Arizona 
26  Legislature  would  effectively  force  a  waiver  of  every  single  legislators  individual 
27  legislative  privilege.  (Defs.  Br.  at  8.)  In  Alliance  for  Global  Justice  v.  District  of 
28  Columbia, plaintiffs sought to compel the District of Columbia to produce a Rule 30(b)(6) 
 
- 6 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 7 of 9
 
 
 
1  deponent to testify about the District Councils collective knowledge of its investigation 
2  into the Districts policing of mass demonstrations. 437 F. Supp. 2d 32, 3435 (D.D.C. 
3  2006). The District asserted that the Councils investigative activities were protected by 
4  the Districts speech and debate statute.2 Id. at 36. In declining to compel the District to 
5  produce a Rule 30(b)(6) deponent, the court explained: 
6  [T]he  [Districts]  speech  and  debate  statute  shields  from  discovery  the 
Councils  knowledge  and  views  of  the  report  and  of  District  policies. 
7  Plaintiffs are seeking testimony relating to a Council investigation, which 
was conducted as part of the Councils deliberative and legislative process. 
8  They also appear to be seeking testimony about the Councils understanding 
and interpretation of its own statutes. Both areas of testimony clearly fall 
9  within the legislative sphere and are shielded by the Districts speech and 
debate statute. Therefore, to the extent that plaintiffs are arguing that the 
10  collective knowledge of the District includes the knowledge of and views 
of the Council, plaintiffs are not entitled to such testimony. The fact that 
11  plaintiffs seek to obtain the Councils knowledge and views via a Rule 
30(b)(6) deponent and disclaim any intention of directly questioning any 
12  Council member or staff is irrelevant. By its very nature, a Rule 30(b)(6) 
deposition  notice  requires  the  responding  party  to  prepare  a  designated 
13  representative [to testify] . . . on matters reasonably known by the responding 
entity. That preparation would require the very type of intrusion into the 
14  Councils  legislative  activities  that  the  speech  and  debate  statute  was 
intended to prevent. 
15 
16  Id. at 37 (emphasis added). 
17    Here, Plaintiffs similarly seek to compel the Arizona Legislature to designate (a) 
18  deponent(s) who can testify as to the collective knowledge of the Legislature.3 (See Pls. 
19 
 
2 Though the court in Alliance for Global Justice considered the Councils evidentiary 
20 
privilege in the context of the Districts speech and debate statute, this does not change this 
Courts analysis. Legislative immunity for state legislators derives from the interpretation 
21 
of federal law and does not depend on the presence of a speech or debate clause in the 
constitution of any State. Lake Country Estates, Inc. v. Tahoe Regl Planning Agency, 440 
22 
U.S. 391, 404 (1979) (citing Tenney, 341 U.S. at 377); Consumers Union of U.S., Inc., 446 
U.S. at 732 (1980). And the logic underscoring legislative immunity supports extending 
23 
the corollary legislative privilege to state legislators as well. Lee, 908 F.3d at 1187; see 
Mi Familia Vota, 2023 WL 4595824, at *7 (explaining that both the legislative privilege 
24 
and legislative immunity involve the core question whether a lawmaker may be made to 
answereither in terms of questions or in terms of defending from prosecution (quoting 
25 
La Union Del Pueblo Entero v. Abbott, 68 F.4th 228, 237 (5th Cir. 2023))).  
3 The parties dispute whether the appropriate defendants are the Speaker and the President 
26 
or the Arizona House of Representatives and the Arizona Senate. (Doc. 500-1, Ex. C, at 
4546; Doc. 500-1, Ex. D, at 50.) The Court need not decide who is the appropriate 
27 
defendant, as the legislative privilege shields the Arizona Legislatures legislative activities 
regardless. See All. for Glob. Justice, 437 F. Supp. 2d at 37 (Regardless of who is the 
28 
defendant, the speech and debate statute shields from discovery the Councils knowledge . 
. . .). 
 
- 7 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 8 of 9
 
 
 
1  Br. at 910 (asserting that the Legislators have necessitated deposition testimony with 
2  respect to the legislature as an entity).) And Plaintiffs proposed deposition topics concern 
3  legitimate legislative activities that fall within the scope of the legislative privilege. 
4  Tenney, 341 U.S. at 376; see Miller v. Transamerican Press, Inc., 709 F.2d 524, 530 (9th 
5  Cir. 1983) (Obtaining information pertinent to potential legislation or investigation is one 
6  of the things generally done in a session of the House, concerning matters within the 
7  legitimate legislative sphere. (internal citations and quotation marks omitted)); Puente 
8  Ariz., 314 F.R.D. at  67071 (finding the legislative  privilege protects a legislators 
9  communications that bear on potential legislation (citation and internal quotation marks 
10  omitted)); Mi Familia Vota, 2023 WL 4595824, at *8 (same); (Doc. 499-1, Ex. 1, at 57 
11  (listing deposition topics).) The Court denies Plaintiffs request to compel the Arizona 
12  House of Representatives and Senate to prepare a 30(b)(6) deponent to testify as to these 
13  topics because doing so would intrude upon the protections afforded by the legislative 
14  privilege. All. for Glob. Justice, 437 F. Supp. 2d at 37; Puente Ariz. 314 F.R.D. at 671 
15  (analyzing the Arizona Legislatures waiver of the legislative privilege as an entity); see 
16  also  Marylanders  for  Fair  Representation,  144  F.R.D.  at  299  (finding  Maryland 
17  legislators preparation and consideration of a legislative redistricting plan fell within the 
18  sphere of legitimate legislative activity and any inquiry into the Maryland Legislatures 
19  consideration of [the plan] . . . [was] entirely barred (second emphasis added)). 
20    Plaintiffs alternatively ask the Court to prevent the Legislators from presenting 
21  arguments on behalf of the Arizona Legislature and require the Legislators to instead 
22  participate as defendants in their individual capacities. (Pls. Br. at 10.) But the Speaker 
23  and the President are authorized to defend Arizonas statutes and the Court declines to limit 
24  their right to represent the Arizona Legislatures interests. A.R.S.  12-1841(D); N.C. State 
25  Conf. of the NAACP, 142 S. Ct. at 2201 (explaining that [s]tates possess a legitimate 
26  interest in the continued enforcement of their own statutes, which may be practically 
27  impaired  or  impeded  if  [their]  duly  authorized  representatives  are  excluded  from 
28  participating  in  federal  litigation  challenging  state  law  (quoting  Cameron  v.  EMW 
 
- 8 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-00509-SRB   Document 535   Filed 09/14/23   Page 9 of 9
 
 
 
1  Womens Surgical Ctr., P.S.C., 142 S. Ct. 1002, 1011 (2022)) (cleaned up) (emphasis 
2  added)). 
3  III.  CONCLUSION 
4    The  Speaker  and  the  President  have  waived  their  legislative  privilege  as  to 
5  information about their motives for the Voting Laws. The Speaker and President must 
6  produce communications that they have sent or received relating to the Voting Laws 
7  legislative process and have withheld on legislative privilege grounds. They may also be 
8  deposed  about  their  personal  involvement  in  the  Voting  Laws  legislative  process. 
9  Plaintiffs may not however conduct a 30(b)(6) deposition of the Arizona Legislature. 
10    IT IS ORDERED granting in part and denying in part Plaintiffs Motion to Compel 
11  (Doc. 500).  
12    IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the Speaker and the President must produce 
13  communications relating to the Voting Laws legislative process that they have sent or 
14  received and have withheld on legislative privilege grounds. 
15    Dated this 14th day of September, 2023.
